question_text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and loose stools with mucus lasting several days to a couple of weeks. She has had these episodes since she was 24 years old but they have worsened over the last 6 weeks. The site of the abdominal pain and the intensity of pain vary. She has around 3–4 bowel movements per day during these episodes. Menses are regular at 31-day intervals with moderate flow; she has moderate pain in her lower abdomen during menstruation. She moved from a different city 2 months ago to start a new demanding job. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her own medications include multivitamins and occasionally naproxen for pain. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
14.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
8100/mm^3

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
15 mm/h

Serum

 Glucose
96 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

 IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody
negative

Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, bloating, and loose stools with mucus lasting several days to a couple of weeks. She has had these episodes since she was 24 years old but they have worsened over the last 6 weeks. The site of the abdominal pain and the intensity of pain vary. She has around 3–4 bowel movements per day during these episodes. Menses are regular at 31-day intervals with moderate flow; she has moderate pain in her lower abdomen during menstruation. She moved from a different city 2 months ago to start a new demanding job. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her own medications include multivitamins and occasionally naproxen for pain. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 110/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 14.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 8100/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 15 mm/h Serum Glucose 96 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody negative Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following in this patient?
hint: The combination of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain with varying location and intensity that are exacerbated by emotional stress, altered bowel habits (change in stool frequency and form), and normal physical examination and laboratory studies (e.g., hemoglobin, ESR) are suggestive of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), which is most commonly seen in individuals aged 20–39 years.
learning_objective: Recognize irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Cutaneous flushing can be caused by carcinoids. These neuroendocrine tumors are usually asymptomatic, as the hormones that they produce (e.g., serotonin) are cleared from circulation by the liver. If they metastasize beyond the liver, however, they can cause symptoms such as diarrhea and cutaneous flushing. This patient is unlikely to have a metastasized carcinoid because of the chronic duration of her symptoms, which do not include further expected signs such as dyspnea and wheezing.

Unintentional weight loss in combination with an 8-year history of chronic episodes of gastrointestinal symptoms may be associated with conditions such as celiac disease, gastric peptic ulcer disease (PUD), or inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, this patient does not have further findings associated with celiac disease (e.g., anemia, steatorrhea, positive IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test), PUD (e.g., dyspepsia, anemia, pain typically worsened by eating), or IBD (e.g., elevated ESR, extraintestinal manifestations).

answers.content: Pruritic vesicles on both elbows and knees
answers.explanation_why: Symmetrically distributed erythematous, pruritic vesicles over the elbows, knees, buttocks, shoulders, or scalp are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis, which is strongly associated with celiac disease. While this patient presents with features of celiac disease, such as loose stools, she does not have any other symptoms of malabsorption (e.g., weight loss, iron deficiency anemia), and her IgA tissue transglutaminase antibody test is negative.

Black, tarry stools (i.e., melena) are most commonly caused by upper gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., variceal hemorrhage due to cirrhosis, peptic ulcer disease), which can manifest with abdominal pain. Other possible causes include right-sided colorectal cancer. This patient does not have features of cirrhosis (e.g., jaundice, ascites), peptic ulcer disease (e.g., epigastric tenderness, dyspepsia), or right-sided colorectal cancer (e.g., anemia, B symptoms).

answers.content: Bright red blood in the stool
answers.explanation_why: Bright red blood in the stool (i.e., hematochezia) is most commonly due to lower gastrointestinal bleeding (e.g., from colorectal cancer, hemorrhoids). Although colorectal cancer can manifest with abdominal pain and loose stools, other findings such as unexplained weight loss or iron deficiency anemia are usually also present. Moreover, colorectal cancer is uncommon in younger patients who do not have a positive family history. If this patient had hemorrhoids, other characteristic findings such as anal pruritus and pain during defecation would be expected. Furthermore, none of these conditions explain this patient's chronic course of symptoms.

answers.content: Relief of abdominal pain after defecation
answers.explanation_why:
Relief of abdominal pain after defecation is often seen in patients with IBS, which is a common chronic gastrointestinal disease with an unknown underlying pathophysiology. In some patients, pain may increase upon defecation or remain unchanged. In the absence of red flag symptoms (e.g., nighttime pain, blood in the stool, weight loss, fever), diagnosis of IBS is based on the Rome IV criteria. Treatment includes regular consultations and reassurance that the disease, although chronic, is benign; dietary adjustments (e.g., avoidance of gas‑producing foods); physical activity; stress management; and possibly psychological therapy.

In patients with suspected IBS and the predominant symptom of diarrhea, additional testing should be considered, e.g., fecal calprotectin or fecal lactoferrin, stool antigen test for Giardia lamblia, serological celiac disease testing, and CRP levels.

Abdominal pain at night, especially in the epigastric region, can be a symptom of duodenal peptic ulcer disease (PUD). PUD is unlikely in this patient considering that other characteristic findings (dyspepsia, anemia, pain relieved by eating) are missing.

question_text: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain for the last 3 hours. He describes the pain as a sharp, substernal chest pain that radiates to the right shoulder; he says “Please help me. I'm having a heart attack.” He has been admitted to the hospital twice over the past week for evaluation of shortness of breath and abdominal pain but left the hospital the following day on both occasions. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol but is a known user of intravenous heroin. He has been living in a homeless shelter for the past 2 weeks after being evicted from his apartment for failure to pay rent. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The patient seems anxious and refuses a physical examination of his chest. His cardiac troponin I concentration is 0.01 ng/mL. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. While the physician is planning to discharge the patient, the patient reports numbness in his arm and insists on being admitted to the ward. On the following day, the patient leaves the hospital without informing the physician or the nursing staff. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of chest pain for the last 3 hours. He describes the pain as a sharp, substernal chest pain that radiates to the right shoulder; he says “Please help me. I'm having a heart attack.” He has been admitted to the hospital twice over the past week for evaluation of shortness of breath and abdominal pain but left the hospital the following day on both occasions. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol but is a known user of intravenous heroin. He has been living in a homeless shelter for the past 2 weeks after being evicted from his apartment for failure to pay rent. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The patient seems anxious and refuses a physical examination of his chest. His cardiac troponin I concentration is 0.01 ng/mL. An ECG shows a normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. While the physician is planning to discharge the patient, the patient reports numbness in his arm and insists on being admitted to the ward. On the following day, the patient leaves the hospital without informing the physician or the nursing staff. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient is most likely seeking an external reward.
learning_objective: Recognize malingering.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with a functional neurological symptom disorder experience neurological symptoms (e.g., numbness, weakness, tremors, pseudoseizures) that are not consistent with any known neurologic disorder and often follow an acute stressor. However, non-neurological symptoms such as substernal chest pain, shortness of breath, or abdominal pain would not be expected. Moreover, unlike this patient, individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder exhibit symptoms in the absence of an obvious external reward.

Individuals with factitious disorder intentionally feign the symptoms of an illness (including induction of injury or disease through self-harm); however, the motive is the emotional support or sympathy (internal reward) obtained by playing the “sick role” and not an external reward (e.g., housing). Moreover, unlike this patient, individuals with a factitious disorder are usually cooperative during their medical evaluation.

Malingering is characterized by the conscious feigning of symptoms (often false or grossly exaggerated) in order to obtain an external reward (e.g., housing, time off from work, narcotics, avoidance of jail time). Individuals are typically uncooperative during their medical evaluation out of fear of being caught, such as this man who refuses a physical examination of the chest. Symptoms usually improve once the desired benefit is obtained. Malingering is not classified as a mental disorder.

Individuals with illness anxiety disorder often have a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalization, and inconclusive diagnostic tests. However, this disorder is characterized by significant anxiety over health and persistent fear (≥ 6 months) of having or developing an illness despite having no or only mild physical symptoms. This patient has intermittent symptoms that started one week ago and he is likely motivated by an external reward, which is not consistent with illness anxiety disorder.

Individuals with somatic symptom disorder report multiple somatic symptoms (e.g., chest pain, shortness of breath, abdominal pain) and often have a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalizations, and inconclusive diagnostic tests. However, the symptoms of somatic symptom disorder persist for a period of ≥ 6 months, occur in the absence of a motive, and cause constant excessive distress to the patient. This patient has only had symptoms intermittently over the past week, is likely motivated by an external reward, and does not appear to be excessively concerned by his symptoms as he left the hospital on multiple occasions without informing the staff.

question_text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after having a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements of his right arm at school. He was sweating profusely during the episode and did not lose consciousness. He remembers having felt a chill down his spine before the episode. Following the episode, he experienced weakness in the right arm and was not able to lift it above his head for 2 hours. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved with over-the-counter medication. He was born at term and his mother remembers him having an episode of jerky movements when he had a high-grade fever as a toddler. There is no family history of serious illness, although his father passed away in a motor vehicle accident approximately 1 year ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 94/54 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, electrolytes, calcium, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after having a 2-minute episode of violent, jerky movements of his right arm at school. He was sweating profusely during the episode and did not lose consciousness. He remembers having felt a chill down his spine before the episode. Following the episode, he experienced weakness in the right arm and was not able to lift it above his head for 2 hours. Three weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved with over-the-counter medication. He was born at term and his mother remembers him having an episode of jerky movements when he had a high-grade fever as a toddler. There is no family history of serious illness, although his father passed away in a motor vehicle accident approximately 1 year ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 94/54 mm Hg. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of glucose, electrolytes, calcium, and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Transient focal weakness following an episode of jerky movements is consistent with the syndrome known as Todd paralysis, which is associated with a particular diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize a focal seizure with Todd paralysis.

answers.explanation_why: Sydenham chorea typically manifests 1–8 months after group A streptococcal infection and is a common form of acquired chorea in childhood. The rapid, irregular, and nonstereotyped movements of Sydenham chorea are usually generalized (involving the head, neck, and limbs) and continuous while the patient is awake, worsening over hours to days. Motor symptoms may be associated with impaired motor control, muscle weakness, and/or hypotonia. While the patient's history of a sore throat 3 weeks ago should raise suspicion of rheumatic fever, the timing of the appearance of the motor disturbance (< 1 month after sore throat), the cessation of the movement after 2 minutes, its restriction to a single limb, and the lack of other criteria suggestive of rheumatic fever make the diagnosis of Sydenham chorea unlikely.

Sporadic transient tic disorder, a subtype of tic disorder, is relatively common during childhood and can include motor tics, which appear as sudden, brief, and intermittent movements that are usually accompanied by an awareness of the urge to perform the tic. However, while the patient did have sudden movements of his arm during the described episode, its duration of minutes rather than seconds, the complexity of the movement, the preceding “chill" (rather than an urge), and the subsequent transient paresis of the affected limb are not consistent with a tic disorder.

Functional neurological symptom disorder is characterized by an unconscious response to psychological stress, either acute or remote, that manifests as a neurological disorder and is distressing for the patient. Possible symptoms include altered motor function, “seizures” of non-epileptic origin, and/or weakness. Criteria for diagnosis include clinical evidence that the symptom cannot be explained by other neurological conditions, making functional neurological symptom disorder a diagnosis of exclusion. While the loss of his father may have caused this patient stress, his symptoms can be explained by a discrete neurological phenomenon.

A migraine may be accompanied by an aura of both positive and negative focal neurologic symptoms such as visual disturbances, paresthesias, or pareses, which usually develop gradually (> 5 minutes) but last no longer than 1 hour and are by definition completely reversible. Hemiplegic migraines specifically are defined by the presence of motor weakness as the manifestation of the aura. Migraines may also be preceded by prodromes occurring 24–48 hours prior to the beginning of the headache, which may include complex experiential symptoms such as depression and euphoria. While this patient did experience a feeling of a “chill down his spine” prior to the episode and subsequent reversible paresis of his arm, he did not experience the headache that is central to the diagnosis of migraine with aura, nor the associated nausea, photophobia, and/or phonophobia. Moreover, the timing of the prodrome and the development and duration of his paresis are not consistent with a migraine aura.

Some patients with migraines may experience aura without an associated headache, also known as a silent migraine, migraine equivalent, or acephalgic migraine. However, this is relatively uncommon, and the majority of patients with hemiplegic migraine have headache with each attack.

A focal seizure may occur with or without dyscognitive features (e.g., loss of consciousness) and can manifest with a variety of positive and negative symptoms, including focal motor activity that may be followed by transient weakness in the affected limb. Focal seizures may arise in the setting of hippocampal sclerosis, infection, trauma, or perinatal injury, among others. The majority of affected patients also experience an aura, with higher cortical sensations such as déjà vu and fear that precede the focal seizure. This patient experienced violent, jerky arm movements preceded by a “chill down his spine” and followed by temporary focal paresis without residual effects (Todd paralysis) upon presentation to the emergency department, which is consistent with the diagnosis of a focal seizure without impairment of consciousness, previously referred to as a simple partial seizure.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her parents because of an irritable mood that started 5 days ago. Since then, she has been staying up late at night working on an art project. She is enrolled in community college and has been able to complete her daily schoolwork and look after her younger brother at home without issues. She feels rested despite sleeping less than 4 hours per night. Her parents also report that she seems easily distracted and more talkative than usual. She has never had similar symptoms before. In the past, she has had episodes where she felt too tired to go to school and slept until 2 PM every day for 2 weeks at a time. During those episodes, her parents noticed that she cried excessively, was very indecisive, and expressed feelings of worthlessness. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. Two months ago, she developed a mild exacerbation that was managed with inhaled albuterol and oral prednisone. She tried cocaine once in high school but has not used it since. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is irritable but cooperative. When asked how she feels, the patient says, “I feel great. I'm not sure why I even need to see a doctor.” Her speech is pressured, and her thought process is linear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her parents because of an irritable mood that started 5 days ago. Since then, she has been staying up late at night working on an art project. She is enrolled in community college and has been able to complete her daily schoolwork and look after her younger brother at home without issues. She feels rested despite sleeping less than 4 hours per night. Her parents also report that she seems easily distracted and more talkative than usual. She has never had similar symptoms before. In the past, she has had episodes where she felt too tired to go to school and slept until 2 PM every day for 2 weeks at a time. During those episodes, her parents noticed that she cried excessively, was very indecisive, and expressed feelings of worthlessness. She has a history of asthma controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. Two months ago, she developed a mild exacerbation that was managed with inhaled albuterol and oral prednisone. She tried cocaine once in high school but has not used it since. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is irritable but cooperative. When asked how she feels, the patient says, “I feel great. I'm not sure why I even need to see a doctor.” Her speech is pressured, and her thought process is linear. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Monotherapy with quetiapine is a first-line treatment option for this patient's condition.
learning_objective: Recognize Bipolar II disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Bipolar II disorder is a subtype of bipolar disorder that is characterized by hypomania and major depression. The distinction between hypomania and mania depends on the intensity and duration of manic symptoms. Hypomania is characterized by manic symptoms (e.g., irritable mood, goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and increased talkativeness in this patient) for ≥ 4 days without significant functional impairment. This patient's hypomania in combination with past major depressive episodes (i.e., excessive fatigue, depressed mood, indecisiveness, and feelings of worthlessness that lasted ≥ 2 weeks) fulfill the criteria for bipolar II disorder.

Bipolar I disorder is a subtype of bipolar disorder that is characterized by at least one manic episode that lasts ≥ 1 week with or without major depressive episodes. Manic episodes cause significant functional (e.g., occupational or social) impairment, often requiring hospitalization, and psychotic features may be present. Although this patient has some manic symptoms (irritable mood, goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, increased talkativeness), they are not severe enough to cause significant impairment; she is able to complete her daily schoolwork and look after her younger brother at home without issues.

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is characterized by ≥ 5 depressive symptoms, one of which must be depressed mood or anhedonia, for a period of ≥ 2 weeks. This patient's 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness (i.e., impacted cognition), and feelings of worthlessness (i.e., guilt) are part of SIGECAPS and fulfill the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder. However, in addition to her depressive episodes, she also exhibits goal-directed behavior, decreased need for sleep, distractibility, and increased talkativeness, which are inconsistent with MDD.

Schizoaffective disorder is characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms with a concurrent mood disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder or bipolar disorder). Although this patient meets the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder (e.g., 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness, and feelings of worthlessness), she does not have psychotic symptoms.

Patients who use stimulant drugs, such as cocaine and methamphetamine, can develop manic symptoms followed by depression. Although this patient has a history of cocaine use, she has not used it since high school and shows no characteristic findings of stimulant use (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis), making this diagnosis unlikely.

Cyclothymia is a milder variant of bipolar disorder in which an individual's mood swings between hypomania and depression, but episodes are not severe enough to establish a diagnosis of bipolar I or bipolar II disorder. Although this patient's hypomanic symptoms are a component of cyclothymia, her depressive symptoms are too severe. Her 2-week periods of tearfulness, fatigue/low energy, hypersomnia, indecisiveness (i.e., impacted cognition), and feelings of worthlessness (i.e., guilt) are part of SIGECAPS and fulfill the clinical criteria for major depressive disorder.

The patient was treated with steroids 2 months ago for an asthma exacerbation. Steroid-induced mania can be seen within days to a few weeks after starting corticosteroid therapy. These symptoms resolve within weeks of discontinuing therapy. This patient has not been using steroids since her asthma exacerbation, and the medication should not be affecting her now.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: The combination of gait abnormalities, dementia, urinary incontinence, and ventriculomegaly without sulcal enlargement in MRI highly suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).
learning_objective: Recognize normal pressure hydrocephalus, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Gradual-onset, mild forgetfulness, hesitant gait, and urinary incontinence may be normal consequences of aging, with risk increasing with advancing age. However, the severity and relative rapidity of this patient's symptoms are unlikely to be part of normal aging. Additionally, this patient's cranial MRI is abnormal.

Increased CSF production (due to choroid plexus neoplasia or inflammation) is a rare cause of communicating hydrocephalus. While communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient.

Degeneration of the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), which causes a characteristic shuffling, short-stepping gait. While this patient is at increased risk of PD given his family history, urinary incontinence and dementia are typically late findings of advanced PD. If this patient had advanced PD, he would have had other earlier signs of the disease (e.g., muscle rigidity, resting tremor, mask-like facies, etc.) for years preceding his current symptoms. Additionally, PD does not explain this patient's abnormal cranial MRI.

Frontotemporal brain atrophy is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which typically presents early on with aphasia and personality changes. This patient's prominent motor/urinary symptoms without substantial personality changes make FTD less likely. Moreover, his cranial MRI does not show frontotemporal atrophy and instead suggests another diagnosis.

images.title: Frontotemporal dementia
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

answers.explanation_why:
Impaired CSF absorption (either idiopathic or due to dysfunction of the arachnoid villi) is the suspected underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of NPH. Impaired CSF absorption leads to transiently elevated intracranial pressure, which causes ventricular enlargement and compression of cerebral structures (e.g., corona radiata). Once the ventricles enlarge, homeostasis between CSF production and resorption is established and intracranial pressure normalizes.

CSF shunting is the main treatment for NPH. The next step in the management of this patient should be to perform a lumbar tap test. Improvement of symptoms after CSF removal strongly supports the diagnosis of NPH and suggests a favorable response to CSF shunting.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of CSF flow causes non-communicating hydrocephalus. While non-communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient. In addition, evidence of an obstructive mass would likely be seen on this patient's cranial MRI.

images.title: Noncommunicating hydrocephalus
images.description:
Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boyA large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

answers.content: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe
answers.explanation_why: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe is found in Alzheimer disease (AD), which commonly causes memory difficulties and enlarged ventricles on cranial MRI. Gait changes and urinary incontinence are typically found in advanced AD years after diagnosis. However, this patient's rapid onset and progression of memory and gait changes associated with urinary incontinence is unlikely to be caused by AD. Moreover, AD usually causes cerebral atrophy (particularly of the hippocampus and temporal lobe), which is not seen on this patient's MRI.

images.title: Cerebral atrophy in Alzheimer disease 2/3
images.description: MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbanceBilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

answers.explanation_why: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare cause of rapidly progressive dementia. While CJD can also cause ataxia and a resulting wide-based gait, more than 90% of patients present with myoclonus and the condition is commonly associated with other neuropsychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations and depression. Also, this patient's MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which is more consistent with another diagnosis.

images.title: MRI in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
images.description: MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

answers.explanation_why: Multiple brain infarctions are characteristic of vascular dementia, which is the second most common form of dementia. This patient is at increased risk of developing vascular dementia given his history of smoking and hypertension, and symptom onset in vascular dementia may be relatively rapid. However, this patient's MRI does not show the expected signs of ischemia (e.g., multiple infarcts), and a stepwise decline in function would be more typical of vascular dementia.

images.title: Subcortical atherosclerotic encephalopathy 2/2
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

question_text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of changes in her sleeping habits. She says that she has been gradually sleeping less over the past couple of months. It takes her 20–25 minutes to fall asleep each night, and she wakes up earlier in the morning than she used to. On average, she sleeps 5–6 hours each night. She says that she has also been waking up several times per night and needs about 20 minutes to fall asleep again. She feels mildly tired in the afternoon but does not take any naps. Her husband reports that she does not snore. She takes a 45-minute walk with her husband and their dog every other day. The patient drinks two cups of coffee each morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she appears cooperative with a full range of affect. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Changes in sleep architecture occur naturally with aging. Sleep disorders (e.g., depression, obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, and GERD) should be also considered if patients are having trouble sleeping.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for an elderly patient with changes in sleep architecture.

answers.explanation_why: Sleep restriction can be used in patients with chronic insomnia in order to reduce sleep latency. This patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal, and therefore this technique is not likely to be significantly beneficial.

Flurazepam can be prescribed for insomnia in patients under 65 years of age. However, flurazepam and other long-acting benzodiazepines are on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to an increased risk of delirium, falls, and motor vehicle crashes. Since this patient is 74 years old, and her sleep changes are likely part of the normal aging process, flurazepam is not indicated.

Melatonin is an important hormone for sleep onset, and melatonin levels decrease with aging. In theory, melatonin should decrease sleep latency, but studies have shown its effect size to be small and potentially clinically insignificant. Furthermore, this patient's sleep latency is within the standard deviation of normal (i.e. < 30 minutes), and it is unclear how much benefit she would receive. A trial of melatonin could be indicated if sleep latency onset increased in this patient.

Changes in sleep architecture that occur naturally with aging are best managed with reassurance and sleep hygiene counseling. Changes include increased sleep latency, longer light stages of sleep with increasing frequency of nighttime awakenings, decreased time in the deep sleep phase (stage 3), shorter REM phases, as well as earlier bedtimes and morning awakenings, all of which can make individuals feel more tired. While such changes may indicate disorders (e.g., advanced sleep phase disorder) and merit treatment, this patient is most likely experiencing normal changes in sleep that occur with aging.

The sedating side effects of diphenhydramine can help patients with increased sleep latency to fall asleep. However, most patients become tolerant to this side effect over the course of a few days. Furthermore, diphenhydramine is on the Beers list of medication that is potentially inappropriate for patients > 65 years of age due to its anticholinergic effects that can precipitate delirium, constipation, dry mouth, and urinary retention. Therefore, diphenhydramine should be avoided in this 74-year-old patient.

Cognitive and behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is the treatment of choice in patients with insomnia disorder. CBT-I combines cognitive therapy, stimulus control, and sleep restriction therapy, sometimes with the addition of relaxation training. Although difficulty initiating and maintaining sleep as well as early morning awakening with the inability to return to sleep are features of insomnia, this patient does not have impaired daytime functioning, which rules out this diagnosis.

Antidepressants, such as trazodone can be used to treat insomnia, especially in patients suffering from depression. This patient's sleep changes are likely related to normal aging, and she lacks the evidence of depression (e.g., restricted affect) for trazodone to be indicated.

question_text:
A previously healthy 21-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of weight loss and fatigue. Over the past 12 months she has lost 10.5 kg (23.1 lb). She feels tired almost every day and says that she has to go running for 2 hours every morning to wake up. She had been a vegetarian for 2 years but decided to become a vegan 6 months ago. She lives with her mother, who has obsessive-compulsive disorder. The mother reports that her daughter refuses to eat with the family and only eats food that she has prepared herself. When asked about her weight, the patient says that despite her weight loss, she still feels “chubby”. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 42 kg (92.6 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 35.7°C (96.3°F), pulse is 39/min, and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows emaciation. There is dry skin, covered by fine, soft hair all over the body. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. Serum studies show:

Na^+

142 mEq/L

Cl
103 mEq/L

K^+

4.0 mEq/L

Urea nitrogen
10 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL

Glucose
65 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 21-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of weight loss and fatigue. Over the past 12 months she has lost 10.5 kg (23.1 lb). She feels tired almost every day and says that she has to go running for 2 hours every morning to wake up. She had been a vegetarian for 2 years but decided to become a vegan 6 months ago. She lives with her mother, who has obsessive-compulsive disorder. The mother reports that her daughter refuses to eat with the family and only eats food that she has prepared herself. When asked about her weight, the patient says that despite her weight loss, she still feels “chubby”. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 42 kg (92.6 lb); BMI is 16 kg/m2. Her temperature is 35.7°C (96.3°F), pulse is 39/min, and blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows emaciation. There is dry skin, covered by fine, soft hair all over the body. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. Serum studies show: Na+ 142 mEq/L Cl 103 mEq/L K+ 4.0 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 10 mg/dL Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL Glucose 65 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This young female has a BMI < 18.5 kg/m^2, follows a strict diet and exercise regimen, and presents with lanugo hair, bradycardia, and hypoglycemia, all consistent with anorexia nervosa. She has acute bradycardia.
learning_objective: Recognize anorexia nervosa with unstable vital signs, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why:
Inpatient nutritional rehabilitation is indicated for patients with anorexia nervosa and unstable vital signs. While most complications of anorexia nervosa can be dealt with in an outpatient setting, this patient's bradycardia (heart rate < 40 bpm) is an indication for hospitalization to prevent syncope, heart failure, and sudden cardiac arrest or death. Bradycardia is a compensatory response to caloric deprivation and generally resolves once the patient's weight is restored by refeeding.

Other criteria for hospitalization include cardiac dysfunction, weight < 70% of ideal body weight or BMI < 15 kg/m^2, and acute medical complications of malnutrition such as syncope, seizures, liver failure, pancreatitis, hypoglycemia, or electrolyte disturbances.

Keeping a food diary may be a useful tool for this patient with anorexia nervosa to increase her awareness of her eating habits. However, her current bradycardia is concerning and requires a different management approach.

While hospitalization is indicated in this bradycardic patient with anorexia nervosa, topiramate would be counterproductive, since it promotes further weight loss. It is rather used off-label in patients with binge eating disorder or bulimia nervosa who are markedly obese.

Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is recommended in patients with anorexia nervosa because starvation may lead to decreased bone density and pathological fractures. However, this patient presents with acute bradycardia, which requires a different treatment approach to prevent sudden cardiac death.

Although hospitalization is indicated in this bradycardic patient with anorexia nervosa, antipsychotic therapy should only be initiated if there is no weight gain despite conservative treatment. Generally, olanzapine is preferred over other antipsychotics such as quetiapine. Olanzapine promotes weight gain and may reduce obsessive thinking. Only low doses should be administered since low weight increases the risk of side effects such as extrapyramidal symptoms and sedation.

Psychodynamic psychotherapy may be helpful in this patient with anorexia nervosa to analyze her interpersonal relationships and factors that possibly contributed to her condition (e.g., obsessive compulsive disorder of her mother). However, her bradycardia needs to be addressed beforehand.

While hospitalization is indicated in this bradycardic patient with anorexia nervosa, fluoxetine therapy is reserved for patients with comorbid depressive or anxiety disorders, which have not resolved with weight restoration. This patient does not report feelings of guilt, anhedonia, or loss of interest, and has not yet received conservative treatment.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy is an essential part of the standard treatment for anorexia nervosa as it may help modify dysfunctional thoughts, alter impaired eating behavior, and modify a patient's attitude towards his or her appearance and weight. However, this patient has acute bradycardia, which should be addressed before initiating psychotherapy to prevent cardiac dysfunction and death.

question_text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpitations, sweating, and flushing. Since he was promoted to a manager in a large software company 6 months ago, he has had several episodes of these symptoms when he has to give presentations in front of a large group of people. During these episodes, his thoughts start racing and he fears that his face will “turn red” and everyone will laugh at him. He has tried to avoid the presentations but fears that he might lose his job if he continues to do so. He is healthy except for mild persistent asthma. He frequently smokes marijuana to calm his nerves. He does not drink alcohol. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler. His pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, the patient appears calm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpitations, sweating, and flushing. Since he was promoted to a manager in a large software company 6 months ago, he has had several episodes of these symptoms when he has to give presentations in front of a large group of people. During these episodes, his thoughts start racing and he fears that his face will “turn red” and everyone will laugh at him. He has tried to avoid the presentations but fears that he might lose his job if he continues to do so. He is healthy except for mild persistent asthma. He frequently smokes marijuana to calm his nerves. He does not drink alcohol. His only medication is an albuterol inhaler. His pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, the patient appears calm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with a 6-month history of physical symptoms (palpitations, sweating, and flushing) during performance situations, resulting in anxious anticipation and avoidance of such situations. These features fulfill the diagnostic criteria for performance-only social anxiety disorder (SAD).
learning_objective: Recognize performance-only social anxiety disorder, and choose the most appropriate initial therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Dialectical behavioral therapy (DBT) is indicated in patients with borderline personality disorder, eating disorders, trauma-related disorders, and depressive disorders associated with suicidal thoughts. DBT is not indicated for patients with performance-only SAD.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a first-line therapy for patients with performance-only SAD, which is a subtype of SAD. CBT includes psychoeducation, cognitive restructuring, and exposure practices to address the anxiety, physiologic responses, and avoidance behaviors. Additionally, beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) or benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam) can be taken 30–60 minutes before an anxiety-inducing event. In this patient, beta-blockers are contraindicated due to his asthma as beta-blockers can cause bronchospasm. Benzodiazepines should also be avoided as marijuana use can exacerbate the adverse effects of benzodiazepines.

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, can provide short-term benefits for patients with performance-only social anxiety disorder when used prior to an anxiety-inducing event. Since lorazepam may cause fatigue and confusion, it should be tried in advance to determine the correct dosage. However, benzodiazepines are not ideal in this patient who frequently uses marijuana because the combination of these two agents may increase side effects such as dizziness, drowsiness, confusion, and difficulty concentrating. Moreover, another treatment would have a longer-lasting effect.

Buspirone is mainly used in generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), which also presents with excessive worrying and physical symptoms of anxiety but involves concerns that are persistent and in other anxiety-inducing areas (i.e., health, work, and finances). Buspirone offers similar efficacy to benzodiazepines without the risk of dependence.

Beta blockers such as propranolol can provide short-term benefits for patients with performance-only SAD when used prior to an anxiety-inducing event. Since propranolol may cause dizziness and fainting, it should be tried in advance to determine the correct dosage. However, beta blockers are contraindicated in this patient with asthma as they increase airway resistance. Moreover, another treatment would have a longer-lasting effect.

SSRIs, such as escitalopram, or SNRIs are the first-line treatment for SAD, which also presents with palpitations, sweating, flushing, and avoidance of social situations. However, in SAD, symptoms of anxiety are not limited to performance situations, but arise in different social situations such as when meeting new people or eating in public.

question_text: An 82-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been waking up early and having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She is worried and feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them and because she feels uncomfortable asking her son to give her a ride, especially since he has been under a great deal of stress lately. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (110 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired and has a flattened affect. Cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: An 82-year-old woman comes to the physician because of difficulty sleeping and increasing fatigue. Over the past 3 months she has been waking up early and having trouble falling asleep at night. During this period, she has had a decreased appetite and a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. Since the death of her husband one year ago, she has been living with her son and his wife. She is worried and feels guilty because she does not want to impose on them. She has stopped going to meetings at the senior center because she no longer enjoys them and because she feels uncomfortable asking her son to give her a ride, especially since he has been under a great deal of stress lately. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 51 kg (110 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is tired and has a flattened affect. Cognition is intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient presents with ≥ 5 symptoms of depression (anhedonia, insomnia, loss of appetite, fatigue, and feelings of guilt) for ≥ 2 weeks, which is suggestive of major depressive disorder (MDD).
learning_objective: Recognize major depressive disorder, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Psychiatric hospitalization is indicated in patients with severe functional impairment and those at imminent risk of harming themselves or others. This patient's MDD may be severe enough to require hospitalization, but to establish this, she should first be properly assessed.

Notification of adult protective services becomes necessary if abuse and/or neglect are suspected. This patient's BMI is normal and physical examination has not revealed signs of malnourishment, dehydration, or physical abuse.

answers.content: Recommend relocation to a nursing home
answers.explanation_why: Recommending relocation to a nursing home could be indicated if the patient's son was unable to properly care for his mother or if there were signs of abuse and/or neglect (e.g., severe dehydration, low BMI), but this is not the case in this patient.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful as an adjunct therapy in patients with MDD, because it can teach stress management, relaxation, and coping techniques, and may improve everyday functioning. However, patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

Family therapy may be helpful in this patient with MDD as an adjunct therapy, especially since there are familial conflicts stressing her. However, it is not the next best step and patient assessment has to be completed beforehand.

This patient may benefit from mirtazapine therapy, a second-line treatment for MDD that would also cause her to gain weight and help improve insomnia due to its sedative effect. However, this patient requires proper assessment prior to initiation of antidepressive therapy.

Suicide screening and assessment is indicated for all patients who display symptoms of MDD. The physician should inquire about suicidal ideation, intent, and plans. Appropriate management depends on the severity of these symptoms and ranges from close observation, psychotherapy, and pharmacotherapy to the involvement of the family and involuntary hospitalization.

question_text: A 22-year-old college student comes to the physician because of depressed mood and fatigue for the past 5 weeks. He has been feeling sad and unmotivated to attend his college classes. He finds it particularly difficult to get out of bed in the morning. He has difficulty concentrating during lectures and often feels that he is less intelligent compared to his classmates. In elementary school, he was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and treated with methylphenidate; he stopped taking this medication 4 years ago because his symptoms had improved during high school. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 8 years; he feels guilty that he has been unable to quit despite numerous attempts. During his last attempt 3 weeks ago, he experienced increased appetite and subsequently gained 3 kg (6 lb 10 oz) in a week. Mental status examination shows psychomotor retardation and restricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 22-year-old college student comes to the physician because of depressed mood and fatigue for the past 5 weeks. He has been feeling sad and unmotivated to attend his college classes. He finds it particularly difficult to get out of bed in the morning. He has difficulty concentrating during lectures and often feels that he is less intelligent compared to his classmates. In elementary school, he was diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and treated with methylphenidate; he stopped taking this medication 4 years ago because his symptoms had improved during high school. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 8 years; he feels guilty that he has been unable to quit despite numerous attempts. During his last attempt 3 weeks ago, he experienced increased appetite and subsequently gained 3 kg (6 lb 10 oz) in a week. Mental status examination shows psychomotor retardation and restricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient presents with depressed mood, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of guilt, and psychomotor retardation for a period > 2 weeks, which is consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD). The sudden weight gain is most likely attributable to his attempt to quit smoking. This patient will benefit most from a medication that can address both MDD and smoking cessation.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for major depressive disorder with a concurrent goal of smoking cessation.

answers.explanation_why: Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant, a class of agents that are the third- or fourth-line treatment for MDD because of their severe side effects, which include anticholinergic symptoms, such as hypotension, arrhythmias and wide QRS complex, and potential risk of lethal overdose. Moreover, amitriptyline has a sedative effect, which is not helpful in this case, as the patient is already suffering from fatigue. Furthermore, this medication does not aid in smoking cessation.

Mirtazapine, which is an atypical antidepressant, is a second-line option for the treatment of MDD. It is particularly useful for patients who would benefit from weight gain since this is one of the agent's main side effects. Mirtazapine also has sedative properties. Considering this patient's recent weight gain, fatigue, and difficulty getting up in the morning, this medication would not be beneficial for him.

Lithium carbonate is used to treat acute mania and manage bipolar disorder. Lithium augmentation may be used in patients with treatment-resistant depression or in suicidal patients to prevent recurrence of suicidal ideation. Side effects include weight gain, tremor, arrhythmias, and hypothyroidism. Since this patient has not received any treatment yet, shows no suicidal ideation, and is already suffering from weight gain, another medication is more appropriate. Furthermore, it does not aid in smoking cessation.

Methylphenidate is a first-line agent for the management of ADHD for patients ≥ 6 years of age. It improves concentration, cognition, short-term memory, and fine motor skills. Side effects include reduced appetite, constipation, hypertension, and decreased growth rate. Although the patient has a history of ADHD, he does not currently exhibit symptoms of hyperactivity, impulsivity, or inattention and would not benefit from this treatment.

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that is commonly used in the management of MDD. Bupropion also aids in smoking cessation, making this an ideal agent for a patient with MDD who wants to quit smoking.

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), a class of agents that are the first-line treatment for MDD, generalized anxiety disorder, and OCD. The antidepressive effect is generally seen within 4–6 weeks of beginning treatment. SSRIs are usually well tolerated. They do not, however, aid in smoking cessation.

Phenelzine is a MAO inhibitor, a class of agents that are the third- or fourth-line treatment for MDD. As this is the first antidepressive medication being prescribed to the patient, another pharmacotherapy should be tried first. Although this class of antidepressants is particularly effective at treating symptoms of atypical depression, including weight gain, this patient's sudden weight gain is likely due to his attempt to quit smoking rather than depression. In addition, MAO inhibitors have potentially life-threatening side effects, including hypertensive crisis secondary to ingestion of foods containing tyramine (e.g., aged cheeses, smoked/cured meats, alcoholic beverages).
Valproic acid is primarily used as an anticonvulsant to treat epilepsy and as a mood stabilizer for bipolar disease. It is not an effective antidepressant, nor does it aid in smoking cessation.

question_text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of difficulty sleeping and poor appetite for the past 4 weeks. During this period, he has also had persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating on tasks, because of which he has been reprimanded at work for poor performance. Over the past 3 years, he has often had such phases, with a maximum symptom-free gap of one month between each of them. His behavior is causing a strain in his relationships with his wife and children. His mother died 4 months ago from breast cancer. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of difficulty sleeping and poor appetite for the past 4 weeks. During this period, he has also had persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating on tasks, because of which he has been reprimanded at work for poor performance. Over the past 3 years, he has often had such phases, with a maximum symptom-free gap of one month between each of them. His behavior is causing a strain in his relationships with his wife and children. His mother died 4 months ago from breast cancer. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
hint: This patient's periods of remission have lasted for ≤ 2 consecutive months.
learning_objective: Recognize persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia).

answers.explanation_why: This patient has depressed mood as well as difficulty sleeping, poor appetite, and poor concentration, all of which are causing psychosocial impairment. These symptoms have been present most of the time for ≥ 2 years in the absence of substance use. Therefore, this patient meets the criteria for persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia). He is likely to benefit from treatment with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and/or psychotherapy.

images.title: Symptom-duration criteria for the diagnosis of mood disorders

answers.explanation_why: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood can manifest with sadness, sleep disturbances, poor appetite, and poor concentration. However, this diagnosis requires the development of depressed symptoms within 3 months of a clear psychosocial stressor and resolution of symptoms within 6 months after termination of the stressor. There is no evidence to suggest that this patient's mood is a reaction to a stressor, and he has had the symptoms for years.

Depressive episodes in bipolar disorder can manifest with sadness, sleep disturbances, poor appetite, and poor concentration. However, diagnostic criteria for bipolar disorder require the presence of at least one manic or hypomanic episode, which this patient lacks.

Although this patient has had several symptoms of major depressive disorder (MDD) for > 2 weeks (sleep disturbance, poor appetite, and poor concentration), he does not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for a MDD, which would require ≥ 5 of the SIGECAPS symptoms.

Although this patient lost his mother 4 months ago, there is no evidence of persistent yearning for her, intense sorrow in response to the death, preoccupation with the deceased or the circumstances of her death, which is required for the diagnosis of persistent complex bereavement disorder. Furthermore, his symptoms began years before the death of his mother.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well and asks for advice about smoking cessation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. She wants to quit smoking but she is not yet ready to set a specific date. She has tried to quit several times in the past without success. During the previous attempts, she had anxiety and gained weight. She has also tried nicotine lozenges but stopped taking them because of severe headaches. She has bulimia nervosa. She does not drink throughout the week but consumes 8–10 alcoholic beverages on weekends. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to behavioral interventions, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding smoking cessation at this visit?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health examination. She feels well and asks for advice about smoking cessation. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years. She wants to quit smoking but she is not yet ready to set a specific date. She has tried to quit several times in the past without success. During the previous attempts, she had anxiety and gained weight. She has also tried nicotine lozenges but stopped taking them because of severe headaches. She has bulimia nervosa. She does not drink throughout the week but consumes 8–10 alcoholic beverages on weekends. She takes no medications. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to behavioral interventions, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management regarding smoking cessation at this visit?
hint: Conditions that increase the risk of seizures (including eating disorders and binge drinking) are a contraindication to certain medications.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation in patients with contraindications to certain medications.

answers.content: No further management at this visit
answers.explanation_why: Some individuals are able to quit smoking without medical intervention. Nevertheless, all patients who wish to quit smoking should be offered medical management. As this patient has tried to quit multiple times, additional management will likely benefit her current attempt at smoking cessation.

Varenicline is a first-line treatment for smoking cessation as it reduces craving and withdrawal symptoms. In patients who are unable to set a quit date, medication preloading with varenicline (i.e., pharmacotherapy while the patient is still smoking) reduces smoking in the weeks leading up to the quit date and increases the likelihood of sustained abstinence rates in the future. In addition to being a safe drug for smoking cessation, varenicline is slightly more effective than bupropion, an alternative management option. A combination of pharmacological and behavioral intervention leads to better results for patients who wish to quit smoking.
Buspirone is a therapy for patients with generalized anxiety disorder and is not a part of smoking cessation management.

Naltrexone is a long-acting opioid antagonist that is used to promote alcohol cessation in patients with alcohol use disorder and to manage withdrawal symptoms after acute opioid detoxification. Although it is being evaluated for its efficacy in smoking cessation, it is currently not recommended as a first-line smoking cessation aid.

Bupropion is a first-line agent for smoking cessation. However, it is contraindicated in patients who have predisposing conditions that increase the risk of seizures (e.g., seizure disorders, anorexia or bulimia nervosa, alcohol withdrawal, abrupt discontinuation of benzodiazepines) because it reduces the seizure threshold.

Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are first-line drugs for the treatment of major depressive disorder (MDD), generalized anxiety disorder, OCD, and bulimia nervosa. They are not an effective therapy for smoking cessation.

question_text: A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician because she has been extremely sad for the past 3 weeks and cries constantly. Three weeks ago, her boyfriend of 4 years left her. She has no appetite and has had a 2.3-kg (5.1-lb) weight loss. She has missed several classes because she could not get out of bed or stop crying. She thinks about her ex-boyfriend all of the time. She says that she experienced similar symptoms for about 2 months after previous relationships ended. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (100 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she appears sad and cries easily. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician because she has been extremely sad for the past 3 weeks and cries constantly. Three weeks ago, her boyfriend of 4 years left her. She has no appetite and has had a 2.3-kg (5.1-lb) weight loss. She has missed several classes because she could not get out of bed or stop crying. She thinks about her ex-boyfriend all of the time. She says that she experienced similar symptoms for about 2 months after previous relationships ended. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (100 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she appears sad and cries easily. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient developed an emotional and behavioral response < 3 months following a stressor that impairs her academic functioning.
learning_objective: Recognize adjustment disorder with depressed mood.

answers.explanation_why: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is characterized by the inability to maintain interpersonal relationships. Although this patient presents with adverse depressive reactions to her breakups, there is no history to suggest that the frequency of her relationships ending is abnormally high (the last relationship lasted ∼ 4 years). Moreover, she does not present with the other characteristic features of BPD such as impulsivity without regard for consequences, a distorted self-image, and fear of abandonment.

Bereavement is associated with grief, which is intense emotional pain and disruption of daily life activities triggered by the death of a close person. The end of a relationship does not qualify as bereavement.

Adjustment disorder with depressed mood is a maladaptive emotional or behavioral response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor (e.g., a breakup) that does not meet the diagnostic criteria for other mental disorders. This patient presents with some features of alternative diagnoses, such as major depressive disorder (depressed mood, loss of appetite), anorexia nervosa (significant weight loss, low BMI), and acute stress disorder (symptom onset < 1 month after a stressor). However, she does not meet the diagnostic criteria for any of these conditions, nor does she have any preexisting psychiatric disorder. This patient cannot get out of bed and has missed several classes, indicating functional impairment that is disproportionate to the stressor.

Adjustment disorder typically resolves within ≤ 6 months following the resolution of the stressor.

images.title: Symptom-duration criteria for the diagnosis of mood disorders

answers.explanation_why: Persistent depressive disorder (PDD) may be suspected in this patient, as she presents with features of a depressed mood, which also occurred after previous breakups. However, PDD is only diagnosed when a patient has a depressed mood on most days for ≥ 2 years, and has never had a symptom-free period longer than 2 consecutive months. This patient was symptom-free for ∼ 4 years (the duration of her last relationship).

Major depressive disorder (MDD) is characterized by anhedonia and depressed mood. Despite having a few of the clinical features of MDD for the required amount of time (> 2 consecutive weeks), this patient does not meet the diagnostic requirement of ≥ 5 criteria and therefore cannot be diagnosed with MDD.

Acute stress disorder (ASD) manifests with the sudden onset of psychiatric symptoms < 1 month after a specific event. However, to meet the criteria for this diagnosis, the event in question must be a traumatic event with exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violation, which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, further symptoms such as intrusion, arousal, and dissociation would be expected in ASD.

This patient is significantly underweight (BMI < 18.5) and has a recent history of significant weight loss, which could be taken as signs of anorexia nervosa (AN). However, a patient with AN would generally present with body image disturbance and physical signs of malnutrition (hypothermia, dry skin, hair loss, muscle wasting, bradycardia, hypotension, and electrolyte disturbances). Moreover, her weight loss is linked to appetite loss, which occurred in response to a specific event.

question_text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of a choking sensation, palpitations, diffuse sweating, and shortness of breath over the past 3 months. These episodes occur without warning and last for about 10 minutes before gradually resolving. One episode occurred while at a shopping center, and she now avoids busy areas for fear of triggering another. She has been evaluated in the emergency department twice during these episodes; both times her ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and serum cardiac enzymes and thyroid hormone levels were normal. She does not currently have symptoms but is concerned that the episodes could occur again at any time and that there may be something wrong with her heart. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of a choking sensation, palpitations, diffuse sweating, and shortness of breath over the past 3 months. These episodes occur without warning and last for about 10 minutes before gradually resolving. One episode occurred while at a shopping center, and she now avoids busy areas for fear of triggering another. She has been evaluated in the emergency department twice during these episodes; both times her ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and serum cardiac enzymes and thyroid hormone levels were normal. She does not currently have symptoms but is concerned that the episodes could occur again at any time and that there may be something wrong with her heart. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has had multiple episodes of panic without a clear identifiable trigger and avoids public places due to fear of recurrence. These features are suggestive of panic disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize panic disorder, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as fluoxetine, are the first-line treatment for panic disorder. This patient has recurrent panic attacks and exhibits all the core components of panic disorder (frequent attacks without an identifiable trigger, anticipatory anxiety). SSRIs have been shown to be effective in reducing the severity of all these features. Moreover, they are associated with a more favorable side effect profile when compared to other medications that may be considered to treat this condition (e.g., benzodiazepines).

D-dimer levels can be used in the diagnosis of suspected pulmonary embolism, which can present with symptoms like tachycardia, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. However, these symptoms would be unlikely to resolve without treatment and the recurrent pattern of her presentation makes this very unlikely.

Propranolol, a beta-blocker, can be used as adjunctive therapy in the treatment of panic disorder and would likely help with her symptom of palpitations. However, beta-blockers have not been shown to be very effective for this disorder and a different medication would be more helpful in the management of this patient.

Buspirone is indicated in the treatment of patients with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). Although this patient has some anxiety-related symptoms, GAD is associated with excessive worrying about everyday tasks, which affects daily functioning, for at least 6 months, rather than anticipatory anxiety of experiencing future panic attacks.

Exposure therapy is used in the management of panic disorders involving a specific phobia. Although this patient now avoids busy spaces, this is secondary to her fear of triggering future panic attacks and not because of a specific phobia. Exposure therapy would not be likely to benefit this patient.

24-hour Holter monitoring is used in the evaluation of suspected cardiac arrhythmia. A paroxysmal arrhythmia (e.g., supraventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, etc) could present similarly with self-resolving episodic palpitations, dyspnea, and diaphoresis. However, her symptoms are secondary to her panic disorder, and the normal ECGs during her attacks make an underlying arrhythmia extremely unlikely.

Echocardiography is used to evaluate for any structural defects of the heart, such as myocardial infarction, valvular dysfunction, and heart failure. She does not have any history to suggest cardiac pathology and echocardiography is not indicated.

Lorazepam and other benzodiazepines can be used to treat acute panic attacks in patients with panic disorder. This patient is not currently experiencing a panic attack, and benzodiazepines should be avoided given their negative side effect profile and high abuse potential. A different management strategy would be more effective for improving her symptoms and minimizing further attacks from occurring.
