question_text: A previously healthy 36-year-old man is brought to the physician by a friend because of fatigue and a depressed mood since his wife left him 4 weeks ago. Since then, the patient has stopped participating in weekly bowling nights with his friends and also missed his friend's bachelor party. He spends his evenings alone at home watching television on the couch. The patient's friend is concerned that he may lose his job because he feels “tired of everything all the time, including work.” He has not missed any work days and has been able to meet all important deadlines. Nearly every night, he wakes up frequently and sometimes takes 20 minutes to go back to sleep. The patient says that he avoids bowling nights because he does not want to see his wife's mutual friends. He also says that he felt too depressed for the bachelor party, which “just did not feel like the right thing at this point in time.” He says that he needs some time to himself in the evening and enjoys watching TV, especially a recent documentary on wildlife in Wyoming. He says that he is planning a trip there to stay alone in a cabin and have some time to think. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He has a flat affect and says that he is going through a difficult phase and does not know how to live without his wife. He denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 36-year-old man is brought to the physician by a friend because of fatigue and a depressed mood since his wife left him 4 weeks ago. Since then, the patient has stopped participating in weekly bowling nights with his friends and also missed his friend's bachelor party. He spends his evenings alone at home watching television on the couch. The patient's friend is concerned that he may lose his job because he feels “tired of everything all the time, including work.” He has not missed any work days and has been able to meet all important deadlines. Nearly every night, he wakes up frequently and sometimes takes 20 minutes to go back to sleep. The patient says that he avoids bowling nights because he does not want to see his wife's mutual friends. He also says that he felt too depressed for the bachelor party, which “just did not feel like the right thing at this point in time.” He says that he needs some time to himself in the evening and enjoys watching TV, especially a recent documentary on wildlife in Wyoming. He says that he is planning a trip there to stay alone in a cabin and have some time to think. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. He has a flat affect and says that he is going through a difficult phase and does not know how to live without his wife. He denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Emotional or behavioral disturbances that occur within 3 months of an identifiable stressor may indicate an adjustment disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize adjustment disorder, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.content: Prescribe a short course of alprazolam
answers.explanation_why: In a patient with adjustment disorder with severe anxiety, a short course of benzodiazepines, such as alprazolam, can be used cautiously. However, this patient does not have symptoms of anxiety (e.g., palpitations, restlessness).

Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) is the treatment of choice for adjustment disorder. This condition is diagnosed in patients with inappropriate or maladaptive emotional or behavioral changes in response to a psychosocial stressor when full criteria for other psychiatric conditions (e.g, major depressive episode) are not met. The goals of cognitive behavioral therapy in patients with adjustment disorder are to identify the stressor, develop methods for reducing stress, and learn coping skills. Pharmacotherapy is usually not required but may be used when psychotherapy alone has little or no effect.

answers.content: Prescribe a short course of sertraline
answers.explanation_why: In a patient with adjustment disorder, an antidepressant can be used if first-line therapy does not result in improvement after 3 months. Treatment with a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, such as sertraline, is indicated for patients with a major depressive episode. However, this patient only meets 4 criteria for a major depressive episode (depressed mood, insomnia, fatigue, flat affect as a sign of psychomotor retardation), and ≥ 5 are needed for a diagnosis.

answers.content: Issue a sick note for time off from work
answers.explanation_why: A medical certificate for sick leave would only result in work absence without addressing the root cause of the patient's emotional and behavioral changes.

Hospitalization is indicated if signs of suicidal ideation or moderate to severe symptoms of alcohol withdrawal are present. However, this patient does not show signs of suicidal ideation or symptoms of alcohol withdrawal.

question_text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit-lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit-lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. A visual field test shows nonspecific visual field defects. An MRI of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with unilateral blindness but has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI.
learning_objective: Recognize functional neurological symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Malingering involves the falsification of manifestations of illness to attain a secondary gain such as financial compensation or time off from work. Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking secondary gain. In addition, patients who malinger typically avoid extensive diagnostic procedures.

Factitious disorder is a condition in which patients intentionally falsify manifestations of illness to assume the role of a sick patient (primary gain). Though this patient has a normal ophthalmologic examination and MRI, there is no indication that she is intentionally falsifying her symptom of blindness or seeking primary gain. Patients usually also have a history of multiple health care visits, are evasive in providing history, and often refuse access to prior medical records.

Central retinal artery occlusion can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have characteristic findings of this condition on fundoscopy such as a pale, edematous retina, and a cherry-red spot near the fovea. In addition, she does not have risk factors for central retinal artery occlusion such as age > 60 years, atrial fibrillation, carotid artery atherosclerosis, or a history of stroke.

images.title: Central retinal artery occlusion
images.description: Left: lateral view of the right eye in longitudinal (sagittal) section. Depiction of an embolism in the central retinal artery causing retinal ischemia.Right: fundus photography of the right eye. Diffuse retinal ischemia causes edema in the inner retinal layers, manifesting as a gray-white discoloration of the retina (most markedly around the fovea; dotted circle). The fovea centralis, where the inner retinal layers are moved to the side, is not affected by edema. The underlying, well-vascularized choroid shines through, appearing as a cherry-red spot.

answers.explanation_why: Retinal detachment can cause sudden, painless, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as prodromal symptoms (e.g., floaters, flashes of light), an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows a retinal tear and a detached, gray, and freely floating retina that moves with eye movements.

Acute stress disorder is a condition that develops after a traumatic event and manifests with symptoms such as anxiety, intrusive thoughts, and negative mood that last between 3 days and 1 month. This condition does not cause somatic manifestations (e.g., blindness).

Somatic symptom disorder is a condition in which a patient has persistent somatic symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue) that result in excessive thoughts and/or behaviors that disrupt daily life. This patient has monocular blindness. However, a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder requires symptoms to persist for ≥ 6 months.

Optic neuritis can cause sudden, monocular vision loss. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as periocular pain, an afferent pupillary defect, or a fundoscopic examination that shows hyperemia and swelling of the optic disc. In addition, optic neuritis typically causes optic nerve inflammation that is visible on MRI.

This patient has functional neurological symptom disorder (FND), a condition that manifests with neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with neurologic disease. She presents with unilateral blindness but has an ophthalmologic examination and MRI that do not indicate an underlying neurologic etiology. FND is more common among young women who have a comorbid psychiatric condition and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., trauma, interpersonal conflict). The diagnosis of this condition requires thorough evaluation and ruling out of other possible diagnoses, such as retinal detachment in this patient with sudden, painless, monocular vision loss.

Patients with FND were classically considered to have la belle indifference, which refers to a lack of concern about their symptoms. However, la belle indifference is not specific to this condition; patients typically have distress and/or impairment.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of chronic abdominal pain that developed after starting a job at a law firm. She also has abdominal bloating and constipation that started 2 weeks ago. She has had no pain with defecation or change in stool form or appearance. She is upset because she has seen two other physicians who performed tests but were unable to make a diagnosis. The patient is currently on sick leave but would like to return to work as soon as possible. She often worries about having a gastric ulcer that may perforate and insists on getting an endoscopy. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that she is under significant pressure from her managers because of frequent performance evaluations. She has a history of childhood asthma. She takes multivitamins and glucosamine daily to prevent arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is mildly distended and slightly tender. The remainder of the examination, including a neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Fecal occult blood test and urea breath test are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of chronic abdominal pain that developed after starting a job at a law firm. She also has abdominal bloating and constipation that started 2 weeks ago. She has had no pain with defecation or change in stool form or appearance. She is upset because she has seen two other physicians who performed tests but were unable to make a diagnosis. The patient is currently on sick leave but would like to return to work as soon as possible. She often worries about having a gastric ulcer that may perforate and insists on getting an endoscopy. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She reports that she is under significant pressure from her managers because of frequent performance evaluations. She has a history of childhood asthma. She takes multivitamins and glucosamine daily to prevent arthritis. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is mildly distended and slightly tender. The remainder of the examination, including a neurologic examination, shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Fecal occult blood test and urea breath test are negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Individuals with this condition typically have a history of visiting multiple physicians.
learning_objective: Recognize somatic symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with adjustment disorder present with a maladaptive emotional and/or behavioral response within 3 months of a stressful event (e.g., cancer diagnosis). Common features include excessive distress and impaired social functioning. Although this patient's symptoms began after starting a new job, her physical findings (e.g., abdominal distention) make adjustment disorder unlikely.

Illness anxiety disorder is diagnosed in individuals with a persistent fear of having or developing an illness in the absence of physical symptoms. Patients may also show maladaptive behavior, such as frequently changing physicians, making it an important differential diagnosis in this patient. Although she spends considerable time worrying about her health, her anxiety is caused by distinct physical symptoms, which are not expected in illness anxiety disorder.

Patients with malingering typically present with vague symptoms and may insist on undergoing extensive medical evaluation. Symptoms in malingering are intentionally fabricated or exaggerated for secondary gain (e.g., in order to get time off from work). There is no evidence that this patient's symptoms are feigned or exaggerated, and she wants to return to work, making another diagnosis more likely.

Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) present with recurrent, nonspecific changes in bowel movements and abdominal symptoms (e.g., diffuse pain, pressure). Diagnostic criteria for IBS consist of abdominal pain on at least 1 day each week during the previous 3 months that is accompanied by at least 2 of the following features: pain with defecation, change in stool frequency, or change in stool form or appearance. Although this patient has had abdominal pain for a year and also reports new-onset constipation, which may manifest with changes in stool frequency and form, constipation has only been present for 2 weeks, meaning that the diagnostic criteria for IBS are not currently fulfilled.

Individuals with functional neurological disorder present with a range of neurological symptoms (e.g., altered sensory function, paralysis with no anatomical pattern) that cause significant psychosocial impairment and that cannot be attributed to a neurological condition. Unlike this patient, individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder are not preoccupied with their health. In addition, this patient does not report any neurological symptoms.

Somatic symptom disorder manifests with one or more physical symptoms that cause significant distress and/or interfere with daily functioning, typically lasting > 6 months. The diagnostic criteria include at least one of the following: disproportionate thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors concerning one's health, excessive anxiety about illness, and inordinate time or resources spent on health concerns. Incidence of somatic symptom disorder is higher in women and in those with a history of chronic childhood illness (e.g., asthma). After ruling out any treatable medical conditions, management consists of reducing unnecessary tests and procedures by scheduling regular appointments and establishing a therapeutic alliance with a single primary care physician. Psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy) may be helpful to treat any underlying psychological causes (e.g., stress) and comorbid psychiatric conditions.

Individuals with factitious disorder typically have a history of seeking care from multiple providers and significant exposure to a healthcare environment (e.g., because of childhood illness) and are willing to undergo invasive treatments. Factitious disorder is characterized by the intentional falsification of an illness and/or its symptoms (e.g., factitious hypoglycemia due to surreptitious insulin use) in order to assume the sick role. There is no evidence of deceptive or attention-seeking behavior by this patient, and her symptoms appear to be genuine.

question_text: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because she has been intermittently crying for 6 hours and does not want to get out of bed. Her symptoms started after she was fired yesterday from her job of 20 years. She says she feels sad and does not understand what she will do with her life now. She uses an over-the-counter inhaler as needed for exercise-induced asthma, and recently started oral isotretinoin for acne. She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but for the last year, she has decreased to two cigarettes daily. She appears sad and upset. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She maintains eye contact and follows instructions. She denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 43-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter because she has been intermittently crying for 6 hours and does not want to get out of bed. Her symptoms started after she was fired yesterday from her job of 20 years. She says she feels sad and does not understand what she will do with her life now. She uses an over-the-counter inhaler as needed for exercise-induced asthma, and recently started oral isotretinoin for acne. She used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day, but for the last year, she has decreased to two cigarettes daily. She appears sad and upset. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is oriented to person, place, and time. She maintains eye contact and follows instructions. She denies suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has experienced an acute stressor, which has triggered symptoms of anxiety (mild tachycardia, tachypnea, and systolic hypertension due to overactivity of the sympathetic nervous system) in addition to symptoms of depression.
learning_objective: Recognize a normal stress reaction.

answers.explanation_why: Although this patient has some symptoms of depression, major depressive disorder can only be diagnosed if the patient's symptoms persist for ≥ 2 weeks and are accompanied by significant social and/or functional impairment.

Patients with an acute stress disorder (ASD) develop symptoms of depression and/or anxiety following exposure to an acute stressor. However, stressors in ASD are usually extremely profound (e.g., exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, sexual violence). The diagnosis of an ASD can only be made if the patient has had symptoms for at least three days. In addition, patients with ASD typically have other features, such as distressing, intrusive thoughts and flashbacks or dissociative amnesia and avoidance of thoughts or feelings related to the event.

Symptoms of depression and/or anxiety in reaction to negative life events are part of the normal emotional response to stress. These symptoms are only considered pathological if their severity exceeds what is normally expected (based on cultural or social norms) and/or if the symptoms are persistent.

Patients with an adjustment disorder can develop symptoms of depression and/or anxiety within 3 months of an acute stressor. However, the diagnosis of an adjustment disorder should only be made when the severity of distress exceeds what would be normally expected (based on cultural or social norms) and/or if the patient's symptoms result in functional impairment. Considering it has only been one day since the event, it is too early to tell if her reaction may cause functional impairment of her everyday life.

Depression has been reported with the use of isotretinoin or inhaled glucocorticoids. However, inhaled glucocorticoids are not available as over-the-counter medications and the evidence that currently exists does not indicate a causative link between isotretinoin and depression. In any case, the onset of distress after getting fired indicates a different cause for the depressive episode.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the Veterans Affairs hospital because of difficulty sleeping for the past 9 weeks. He is a soldier who returned from a deployment in Afghanistan 12 weeks ago. Fifteen weeks ago, his unit was ambushed in a deserted street, and a fellow soldier was killed. He wakes up frequently during the night from vivid dreams of this incident. He blames himself for being unable to save his friend. He also has trouble falling asleep and gets up earlier than desired. During this period, he has started to avoid walking in deserted streets. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. He refuses cognitive behavioral therapy and is started on sertraline. Seven weeks later, he returns to the physician and complains about persistent nightmares and difficulty sleeping. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the Veterans Affairs hospital because of difficulty sleeping for the past 9 weeks. He is a soldier who returned from a deployment in Afghanistan 12 weeks ago. Fifteen weeks ago, his unit was ambushed in a deserted street, and a fellow soldier was killed. He wakes up frequently during the night from vivid dreams of this incident. He blames himself for being unable to save his friend. He also has trouble falling asleep and gets up earlier than desired. During this period, he has started to avoid walking in deserted streets. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. He refuses cognitive behavioral therapy and is started on sertraline. Seven weeks later, he returns to the physician and complains about persistent nightmares and difficulty sleeping. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: After experiencing a traumatic event, this soldier is haunted by nightmares, expresses self-blame, has difficulty sleeping, and avoids situations that remind him of the incident for > 1 month, which fulfills the diagnostic criteria for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate next step in management for PTSD-related sleep disturbances.

answers.explanation_why: Diazepam, a long-acting benzodiazepine, may be beneficial in the treatment of anxiety and hyperarousal symptoms of PTSD (e.g., insomnia, irritability). However, there is a high potential for addiction to benzodiazepines, especially in patients with PTSD. Benzodiazepines may also cause mental clouding and interfere with cognitive behavioral therapy. For these reasons, benzodiazepines are currently not recommended as first-line therapy for PTSD.

Zolpidem, a nonbenzodiazepine, has sedative and hypnotic effects, which make this drug useful in the management of insomnia. Although this patient does have difficulty falling asleep, a common side effect of zolpidem is nightmares, meaning zolpidem may even worsen the patient's symptoms.

Triazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine and is helpful in the management of patients with insomnia. However, a common side effect of triazolam is vivid dreams and nightmares. This patient already has vivid dreams of the traumatic incident, and triazolam could worsen his symptoms. Moreover, benzodiazepines should generally be avoided in patients with PTSD due to the risk of drug misuse and lack of evidence supporting the benefits.

Phenelzine is a nonselective monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) that may be used to treat insomnia in patients with PTSD who do not respond to other treatment. MAOIs are not preferred as first-line pharmacotherapy in PTSD due to their potentially harmful side effects (hypertensive crisis if coingested with tyramine-containing foods, serotonin syndrome, and risk of fatal overdose).

Prazosin therapy is used to decrease the frequency of nightmares and improve sleep quality in patients with PTSD, particularly in combat veterans and in patients experiencing nighttime PTSD symptoms (e.g., nightmares, sleep disturbances). Since this patient has vivid dreams of the traumatic incident on a regular basis, difficulty falling asleep, and poor sleep quality despite using a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), a trial of prazosin would be indicated.

Ideally, PTSD is treated with a combination of trauma-focused psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. The first-line pharmacotherapy in patients with PTSD is an SSRI (e.g., paroxetine, fluoxetine) or selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., venlafaxine).

Supportive psychotherapy focuses on guidance, reinforcement, and encouragement to build self-esteem and improve functioning in social environments for patients suffering from anxiety disorders. However, exposure-based or trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy (which involves having the patient repeatedly reexperience the traumatic event) is the psychotherapy of choice in patients with PTSD.

Interpersonal therapy is mainly used in the management of patients with depression since these patients often have difficulties interacting with others. Trauma-focused or exposure-related cognitive behavioral therapy (which involves having the patient repeatedly reexperience the traumatic event) is the psychotherapy of choice in patients with PTSD, however; it aims to alter the distorted and irrational beliefs/attitudes (guilt and blaming oneself, in this case) from which these patients suffer.

question_text: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took on an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pinprick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man comes to the emergency department with his wife because of a 3-day history of severe pain in his right arm. He also reports that he cannot move his right arm. The symptoms began after the patient woke up one morning, having slept on his side. He is otherwise healthy. He works as a waiter and says that he feels exhausted from working several night shifts per week. He adds that he “can barely keep his eyes open” when looking after their daughter the next day. Since the onset of the pain, he has been unable to work and is fully dependent on his wife, who took on an extra shift to make enough money to pay their monthly bills. The patient appears relaxed but only allows himself to be examined after his wife convinces him. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1/5 muscle strength in the right arm. Reflexes are normal. He has no sensation to light touch over the entire right arm and forearm. When a pinprick test is conducted, the patient rapidly withdraws the right arm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient reports paralysis and pain in his right arm, but clinical findings are inconsistent with his statements and indicate that movement is preserved. The fact that he is reluctant to undergo examination should raise concern that an external reward is at stake (e.g., time off from work and potentially obtaining insurance money).
learning_objective: Recognize malingering.

answers.explanation_why: Brachial neuritis can cause severe, unilateral shoulder pain, weakness, and sensory loss. In brachial neuritis, however, shoulder pain and neurological deficits do not occur simultaneously; neurological deficits only occur as the pain begins to subside. Moreover, this patient does not have a true neurological deficit because the deep tendon reflexes, pain sensation, and withdrawal reflex are intact.

Individuals with factitious disorder often report symptoms that are inconsistent with examination findings. However, patients with factitious disorder intentionally feign the symptoms of an illness, the motive for which is the emotional support or sympathy obtained by playing the “sick role” and not an external benefit (e.g., time off from work, financial compensation). Moreover, patients with a factitious disorder are usually cooperative during physical examination.

Individuals with somatic symptom disorder report somatic symptoms (e.g., shoulder pain, weakness) that cause excessive distress for a period of ≥ 6 months. There is usually a history of frequent visits to physicians, hospitalization, and extensive diagnostic tests. Patients with somatic symptom disorder are also distressed by the fact that they do not obtain relief from symptoms. This patient has only had symptoms for the past three days and is very possibly motivated by an external reward, neither of which is consistent with somatic symptom disorder.

Arm weakness with decreased sensation to light touch on the arm and forearm but intact pain sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and withdrawal reflex is not consistent with any known neurological disorder. In malingering, patients intentionally feign symptoms of a physical or psychiatric illness to obtain an external benefit (e.g., time off from work, financial compensation, avoiding jail). These individuals are also typically uncooperative during physical examination. Malingering is not a mental disorder.

Patients with malingering should be approached in a nonthreatening, calm, distant yet empathetic manner to improve the physician-patient relationship and give the patient the opportunity to be honest without becoming uncomfortable and possibly compromising this relationship.

Individuals with functional neurological symptom disorder experience neurological symptoms that are not consistent with any known neurologic disorder (e.g., arm weakness with decreased light touch sensation in the arm and forearm but intact pain sensation, deep tendon reflexes, and withdrawal reflex) and may be calm when describing their symptoms. However, there is no external motive for feigning symptoms and individuals usually have a history of an underlying depressive or anxiety disorder. Functional neurological symptom disorder is also more common among women than men and typically occurs during adolescence or early childhood.

Radial nerve palsy may occur as a result of nerve compression. Compression of the radial nerve only impairs forearm supination, forearm, wrist, and finger extension, and sensory perception on the dorsal surface of the upper limb. Severe shoulder pain, weakness of both flexors and extensors in the arm, and sensory loss on the dorsal and ventral surfaces of both the arm and forearm are not consistent with radial nerve palsy. Moreover, this patient does not have a true neurological deficit because deep tendon reflexes, sensitivity to pain, and the withdrawal reflex are intact.

Illness anxiety disorder is diagnosed in individuals with a persistent fear (lasting ≥ 6 months) of having or developing an illness despite having no or only mild physical symptoms. This patient reports severe symptoms that started only three days ago and he is very possibly motivated by an external reward, neither of which is consistent with illness anxiety disorder.

question_text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a 12-hour history of agitation and bizarre behavior. The girlfriend reports that, over the past 3 months, the patient has become withdrawn and stopped pursuing hobbies that he used to enjoy. Around that time, he started to become apprehensive about leaving his apartment and began to express suspicions that the FBI was trying to control his mind. One month ago, he lost his job because he stopped going to work to avoid being spied on. He used to smoke cannabis occasionally in high school but quit 5 years ago. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. His speech is disorganized and his affect is labile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his girlfriend because of a 12-hour history of agitation and bizarre behavior. The girlfriend reports that, over the past 3 months, the patient has become withdrawn and stopped pursuing hobbies that he used to enjoy. Around that time, he started to become apprehensive about leaving his apartment and began to express suspicions that the FBI was trying to control his mind. One month ago, he lost his job because he stopped going to work to avoid being spied on. He used to smoke cannabis occasionally in high school but quit 5 years ago. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and suspicious with marked psychomotor agitation. His speech is disorganized and his affect is labile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with acute agitation, disorganized speech, and bizarre behavior following a 3-month history of delusions, social withdrawal, and anhedonia that affected his social and occupational functioning.
learning_objective: Recognize schizophreniform disorder.

answers.explanation_why: The diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder requires that patients meet the criteria for a mood disorder (major depressive episode or manic episode) while exhibiting psychotic symptoms consistent with schizophrenia. In addition, psychotic symptoms must be present in the absence of mood disorder symptoms for at least 2 weeks. This patient does not meet the criteria for a mood disorder episode.
Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms lasting > 1 day but ≤ 1 month and is usually triggered by stressful situations. This patient's symptoms began three months ago.

This patient shows signs of social withdrawal, a preference for solitary activities, and reduced affect, which are all features of schizoid personality disorder. However, personality disorders are pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality patterns that arise during adolescence, lead to distress or impairment, and are stable over time. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder generally do not have the desire for close relationships. They show little interest in interpersonal or sexual contact and often appear indifferent or emotionally cold towards others. This diagnosis is unlikely given the fact that he has a girlfriend and developed symptoms three months ago.

A number of prescription drugs (e.g., benzodiazepines) and illicit drugs (cannabis, alcohol) can cause substance-induced psychotic disorder. Symptoms generally occur during or shortly after exposure, intoxication, or withdrawal. There is no evidence of current substance abuse in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely. Frequent use of cannabis is, however, associated with an increased risk of psychosis and schizophrenia.

Paranoid personality disorder, like all personality disorders, is a pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality pattern that arises during adolescence, leads to distress or impairment and is stable over time. Patients tend to be suspicious of other people's intentions, often reading hidden meaning or threats into benign events, and do not confide in others for fear of being deceived or exploited. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient given the fact that he developed symptoms three months ago.
Although this patient's clinical presentation is consistent with schizophrenia, symptoms must cause social, occupational, or personal functional impairment lasting ≥ 6 months for this diagnosis.

Schizophreniform disorder is a clinical diagnosis that is made using the same diagnostic criteria as schizophrenia. The main difference, however, is the duration of the disorder. Schizophreniform disorder is diagnosed in patients who present with delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and/or negative symptoms that impair social, occupational, and personal functioning over a period of 1–6 months (see “Psychotic disorders” table). If symptoms persist for ≥ 6 months, the diagnosis must be changed to schizophrenia. About one-third of patients recover, while the other two-thirds go on to develop schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder.

Schizotypal personality disorder, like all personality disorders, is a pervasive, inflexible, and maladaptive personality pattern that arises during adolescence, leads to distress or impairment and is stable over time. Patients typically exhibit odd, eccentric behavior and describe unusual beliefs and experiences. They may express suspicion of other people's intentions, and social and interpersonal interactions usually cause them discomfort. Psychotic symptoms would not be expected.

Although this patient exhibits signs consistent with delusional disorder (e.g., delusions, paranoia), he also has other symptoms that affect his social and occupational functioning, including disorganized speech and behavior, social withdrawal, and anhedonia. Delusional disorder is therefore an unlikely diagnosis.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time in his room playing online games. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. Rather than doing his coursework, he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon.” Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the physician by his mother because she is worried about his strange behavior. Over the past 3 years, he has been dressing all in black and wears a long black coat, even in the summer. The mother reports that her son has always had difficulties fitting in. He does not have any friends and spends most of his time in his room playing online games. He is anxious at college because he is uncomfortable around other people, and his academic performance is poor. Rather than doing his coursework, he spends most of his time reading up on paranormal phenomena, especially demons. He says that he has never seen any demons, but sometimes there are signs of their presence. For example, a breeze in an enclosed room is likely the “breath of a demon.” Mental status examination shows laborious speech. The patient avoids eye contact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has a cluster A personality disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize schizotypal personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and difficulty developing meaningful social relationships. However, a key component of schizoid personality disorder is a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and limited range of emotional expression. Patients are content with social isolation and do not seek relationships. Although this patient does not have friends and spends most of his time alone, patients with schizoid personality disorder would be more indifferent about social interactions than anxious. Furthermore, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by this diagnosis.

Patients with social anxiety disorder have anxiety in social situations. However, their anxiety is driven by an intense fear of embarrassment in social situations. Furthermore, this patient's odd beliefs, magical thinking, and unusual clothing could not be explained by this disorder.

Patients with avoidant personality disorder are uncomfortable around other people and avoid social settings. Their discomfort is driven by a feeling of inadequacy and/or an intense fear of rejection or embarrassment, and they tend to desire interpersonal relationships even if they are anxious about interacting with others. However, this patient's social withdrawal appears voluntary and his odd beliefs and unusual clothing choices would not be explained by this diagnosis.

Schizotypal personality disorder usually manifests with odd and eccentric behavior and appearance. Patients also tend to have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. Moreover, excessive social anxiety, odd speech, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are usually also seen.

See “Overview of cluster A personality disorders” table.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is usually diagnosed in young children who present with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. Although this young man is uncomfortable around other people, his age and the absence of additional symptoms of ASD, including impaired language skills or repetitive movements and behavior, makes the diagnosis unlikely. The diagnosis of ASD would also not explain this patient's preoccupation with paranormal phenomena.

Patients with paranoid personality disorder are generally emotionally isolated and have eccentric behavior. However, a key component of paranoid personality disorder is suspicion of and distrust toward others due to the belief that others have malicious intentions. Although this patient is uncomfortable around other people, he is not described as being suspicious of them. Furthermore, paranoid personality disorder is not typically associated with odd and magical thinking.

Patients with schizophrenia present with chronic and recurrent psychosis for more than 6 months. These patients tend to initially present with a prodrome of negative symptoms characterized by social withdrawal, which is then followed by positive psychotic symptoms (i.e., hallucinations, delusions, and bizarre behaviors). Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, he does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of schizophrenia, as he has no clear delusions or hallucinations and no disorganized speech.

This patient's laborious speech is not the same as disorganized speech. Laborious speech is nonfluent speech that requires excessive effort and lacks spontaneity, but the thought processes and the contents of the speech are intact. On the other hand, disorganized speech results from disorganized thought processes and can manifest as loose associations (illogical, sudden, and frequent changes of topic), word salad (sequence of words without a logical connection), and flight of ideas (quick succession of thoughts), none of which are evident in this patient.

question_text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for right arm and leg weakness, numbness, and tingling that has been resolving gradually. The symptoms started 4 hours ago, after she had an argument with her boyfriend. She says she has been limping and cannot use her right arm anymore. She has never had similar symptoms in the past. She has a history of genital herpes and trichotillomania. She is alert and oriented. Physical examination shows upper and lower face symmetry and normal speech. She has 5/5 strength in all extremities and 5/5 right ankle plantar flexion when lying down. She has 4/5 strength in the right arm and leg when ambulating. She cannot stand on her toes when asked. Her deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. She has normal proprioception, light touch sensation, and two-point discrimination in all extremities. She has a negative Spurling test. CT of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for right arm and leg weakness, numbness, and tingling that has been resolving gradually. The symptoms started 4 hours ago, after she had an argument with her boyfriend. She says she has been limping and cannot use her right arm anymore. She has never had similar symptoms in the past. She has a history of genital herpes and trichotillomania. She is alert and oriented. Physical examination shows upper and lower face symmetry and normal speech. She has 5/5 strength in all extremities and 5/5 right ankle plantar flexion when lying down. She has 4/5 strength in the right arm and leg when ambulating. She cannot stand on her toes when asked. Her deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. She has normal proprioception, light touch sensation, and two-point discrimination in all extremities. She has a negative Spurling test. CT of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This young female patient has a history of psychiatric illness (trichotillomania) and presents with isolated neurological symptoms following an emotional stressor. Imaging shows no abnormalities, and focal neurological findings are inconsistent, which is highly characteristic of functional neurological symptom disorder (FNSD).
learning_objective: Recognize functional neurological symptom disorder, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective long-term treatment for FNSD. Strategies for treating FNSD with CBT include establishing a shared understanding of the diagnosis, identifying treatment goals, challenging maladaptive behaviors and thoughts (e.g., thinking of functional impairment as permanent), and realistically anticipating setbacks in the treatment course. However, this patient has new-onset FNSD, and another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

Patients with FNSD that does not improve with conservative therapies may benefit from antidepressants like citalopram, which can treat both FNSD and common comorbidities such as generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder. However, antidepressants are not the recommended first-line treatment for FNSD.

Alteplase (tPA) is appropriate for treating stroke. Although this patient's symptoms began 4 hours ago, which is within the therapeutic window for thrombolysis (i.e., within 4.5 hours of symptom onset), she has an inconsistent neurological exam, and CT of the head was negative for acute intracranial abnormalities, making a cerebrovascular condition unlikely.

Patient education is the initial step in management of FNSD, as symptoms may resolve after an explanation of the condition and its causes. Strategies for patient education include asking about their perspective of the problem, taking their symptoms seriously, explaining clinical features that are inconsistent with neurological disease, and emphasizing that symptoms are often reversible. Cognitive behavioral therapy can further help patients to understand and manage their symptoms. Pharmacotherapy (e.g., antidepressants, anxiolytics, or mood stabilizers) can be considered for patients with a comorbid psychiatric disorder.

Physical therapy may be useful as an adjunctive treatment for patients with motor symptoms of FNSD, but it is not the most appropriate initial step in management of new-onset FNSD. Strategies for treating FNSD with physical therapy include encouraging normal functional movement (e.g., transfers and walking) and teaching patients to suppress abnormal movements or deficits (e.g., using distraction techniques).

Patients who do not respond to other conservative treatment approaches for FNSD may benefit from biofeedback, especially individuals with functional tremors. In this patient, another management approach should be tried first.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath, sweating, and dizziness over the past 4 months. These episodes are accompanied by an intense fear of “losing control” over himself. Most of the episodes have occurred at work in situations when it would have been unacceptable to leave, such as during team meetings. The last episode occurred at home right before this visit, after he noticed that he was running late. He has been otherwise healthy. He occasionally drinks a beer or a glass of wine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid function studies and an ECG show no abnormalities. Given his symptoms, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?

Most of the episodes have occurred at work in situations when it would have been unacceptable to leave, such as during team meetings. The last episode occurred at home right before this visit, after he noticed that he was running late. He has been otherwise healthy. He occasionally drinks a beer or a glass of wine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid function studies and an ECG show no abnormalities. Given his symptoms, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with recurrent episodes of intense anxiety combined with the feeling of losing control and physical symptoms such as palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath, sweating, and dizziness. These features suggest panic disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize panic disorder, and recall its psychiatric comorbidities.

answers.content: Preoccupation with an observed flaw in physical appearance
answers.explanation_why: Obsessive preoccupation with an observed flaw in one's physical appearance is a typical feature of body dysmorphic disorder (BDD). Although BDD is associated with a variety of psychopathologies, including panic disorder, other comorbidities and associated symptoms are more common.

Inability to recall autobiographical information is a typical symptom of individuals with dissociative amnesia. Although panic attacks can cause dissociative symptoms, dissociative disorders are typically preceded by psychological trauma (often in the patient's childhood).

Intrusive thoughts and irresistible impulses are typical symptoms of individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Although anxiety disorders such as panic disorder are associated with OCD, other comorbidities and associated symptoms are more common.

answers.content: Abnormally elevated mood and flight of ideas
answers.explanation_why: Abnormally elevated mood and flight of ideas are characteristic of manic episodes in individuals with bipolar disorder. Although bipolar disorder can be comorbid with panic disorder, other comorbidities and associated symptoms are more common.

answers.content: Depressed mood and feeling of guilt
answers.explanation_why: Individuals with panic disorder are at increased risk of developing other psychiatric disorders, including agoraphobia, social anxiety disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder, substance use disorders, and major depressive disorder (MDD). MDD typically presents with a depressed mood and a feeling of guilt. Approximately 50% of patients with panic disorder have at least one episode of MDD in their lifetime.

The fear of certain animals, such as spiders (arachnophobia), or natural environments, such as heights (acrophobia), is a type of specific phobia, and specific phobias are associated with panic disorder. However, animal phobias typically develop in early childhood. A different comorbidity is more likely to occur in this patient.
Disorganized speech and delusions are typical symptoms of schizophrenia. Rarely, schizophrenia can be comorbid with panic disorder, but other comorbidities and associated symptoms are more common.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a rest area along an interstate highway in Florida. She is unable to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person. She denies being the woman on the Connecticut driver's license found in her wallet.  A telephone call with the police department of her hometown reveals that she had been reported missing three days ago by her husband. When the husband arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and that before she went missing, she was anxious about telling her boss that she will not meet the deadline for her current project. She has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to time and place but not to person. Short-term memory is intact; she does not recognize her husband or recall important life events. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a rest area along an interstate highway in Florida. She is unable to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person. She denies being the woman on the Connecticut driver's license found in her wallet. A telephone call with the police department of her hometown reveals that she had been reported missing three days ago by her husband. When the husband arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and that before she went missing, she was anxious about telling her boss that she will not meet the deadline for her current project. She has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to time and place but not to person. Short-term memory is intact; she does not recognize her husband or recall important life events. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's disorder is often connected to a stressful or traumatic event.
learning_objective: Recognize dissociative amnesia.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's inability to recall autobiographical information after a stressful event at work raises suspicion for dissociative amnesia. Since this patient's episode of dissociative amnesia involved traveling away from her usual surroundings, the specifier “dissociative fugue” applies. The diagnosis is further supported by the significant social impairment associated with her symptoms and the absence of a physiological (e.g., traumatic brain injury, transient global amnesia), psychiatric (e.g., dissociative identity disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder), or substance-related (e.g., alcohol use disorder, medication adverse effects) cause for her presentation.

Dissociative identity disorder can result in the inability to recall personal information or events of daily life. Wandering or purposeful travel of which the patient has no recollection is a possible feature of dissociative identity disorder that is seen in this patient. The diagnosis of dissociative identity disorder requires the presence of at least two distinct personality states that cause identity disruption and dominate at different times. As there are no signs of this in this patient at this point, dissociative personality disorder would not be the right diagnosis.

Depersonalization disorder does not usually cause gaps in memory. Instead, it is characterized by feeling detached with respect to one's own thoughts, feelings, body, and actions, which is not the case in this patient.

Korsakoff syndrome causes selective amnesia, which can be both anterograde and retrograde. However, Korsakoff syndrome develops as a consequence of long-term thiamine deficiency, which typically occurs in individuals with alcohol use disorder. Even though this patient does consume alcohol on a regular basis, her examination shows no signs of thiamine deficiency (e.g., ataxia, nystagmus, apathy, indifference, confabulation).

Delirium is an acute disorder that can also cause deficits in memory and confusion. Delirium can be triggered by many factors, including psychoactive drugs, such as citalopram, which this patient had been taking. However, the patient is lacking all other typical findings of delirium, such as illusions, hallucinations, or reversal of the sleep-wake cycle.

Memory impairment is the most prominent finding in major neurocognitive disorder (dementia). However, early-onset dementia in a 28-year-old patient is extremely unlikely, as early-onset dementia mostly affects people in the fifth and sixth decade of life. In addition, this patient's memory loss and impairment of spatial-temporal awareness seem to be only of episodic character and the patient is lacking other typical findings of major neurocognitive disorder, such as speech difficulty and difficulty with reasoning.

question_text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because he has become increasingly restless and anxious. His wife says that he has seemed sad and irritable for the past 4 months. He lost his job as a store clerk 1 year ago because he often lied to avoid work, and spent most of his days on the phone placing bets on football games. He avoids all family-related events because he has borrowed money from most of his relatives. He is hopeful that his symptoms will improve once he is able to win some of his money back. He previously smoked 8–10 cigarettes daily but quit 1 month ago. He drinks beer on the weekends. On examination, he is uncooperative and dismissive. He is mildly tremulous. Neurologic examination is normal. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 48-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because he has become increasingly restless and anxious. His wife says that he has seemed sad and irritable for the past 4 months. He lost his job as a store clerk 1 year ago because he often lied to avoid work, and spent most of his days on the phone placing bets on football games. He avoids all family-related events because he has borrowed money from most of his relatives. He is hopeful that his symptoms will improve once he is able to win some of his money back. He previously smoked 8–10 cigarettes daily but quit 1 month ago. He drinks beer on the weekends. On examination, he is uncooperative and dismissive. He is mildly tremulous. Neurologic examination is normal. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient has depressed mood and his behavior has caused significant dysfunction in his life.
learning_objective: Recognize gambling disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Major depressive disorder is characterized by depressed mood and/or anhedonia lasting more than 2 weeks. While this patient displays some symptoms consistent with depression (e.g., restlessness, depressed mood), he does not meet the DSM-V criteria of ≥ 5 SIG E CAPS symptoms.

Nicotine withdrawal can cause tremulousness, irritability, and a depressed mood. However, symptoms usually occur within 24 hours of stopping cigarette smoking and generally improve with time (sometimes up to 4 weeks). This patient stopped smoking 1 month ago but his symptoms were present prior to cessation.

This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for gambling disorder, which requires that individuals exhibit ≥ 4 criteria within a 12-month period. He is preoccupied with gambling, has lost his job because of gambling, relies on money provided by others, becomes irritable or anxious when he has to stop gambling, and plans on recouping his losses by winning them back. Treatment consists of group therapy and cognitive behavioral therapy.

Opioid withdrawal is classically characterized by diarrhea, flu-like symptoms, insomnia, irritability, anxiety, and even aggression. While this patient's presentation does have some features consistent with this diagnosis, there is no history of opioid use and his constellation of symptoms suggests an alternate disorder.

Acute stress disorder is characterized by anxiety-related symptoms occurring within one month following a traumatic event. This patient does not have history of a traumatic event and his combination of symptoms suggests an alternate diagnosis.

Patients with alcohol withdrawal can present with irritability and tremulousness. Alcohol withdrawal is a serious condition and should not be overlooked, but his history of only drinking on the weekends would be inconsistent with this diagnosis.

Bipolar disorder should be on the differential for this patient, as he has some features of a major depressive episode (e.g., restlessness, depressed mood), evidence for significant dysfunction (losing his job), as well as irritable mood. However, he does not have a history of manic episodes and his current symptoms do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode (e.g., ≥ 4 symptoms such as flight of ideas, pressured speech, decreased need for sleep). Therefore, he does not meet criteria for either type I or type II bipolar disorder.

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional and behavioral changes within 3 months of a stressful event (and resolution within 6 months). However, this patient meets criteria for a different disorder and has no history of traumatic event.

question_text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 10-month history of repeated behavioral problems. Her teachers describe her behavior as uncooperative and disruptive as she persistently refuses to answer questions, insults her teachers, and deliberately distracts her classmates. At home, her parents try to address her frequent violations of curfew but attempts to discuss the issue often result in their daughter losing her temper and screaming at her parents. Her grades have deteriorated over the past year. When listening to music or hanging out with friends, she is calm and pleasant. She has no history of psychiatric illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and frequently disrupts the physician’s conversation with the parents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 10-month history of repeated behavioral problems. Her teachers describe her behavior as uncooperative and disruptive as she persistently refuses to answer questions, insults her teachers, and deliberately distracts her classmates. At home, her parents try to address her frequent violations of curfew but attempts to discuss the issue often result in their daughter losing her temper and screaming at her parents. Her grades have deteriorated over the past year. When listening to music or hanging out with friends, she is calm and pleasant. She has no history of psychiatric illness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is uncooperative and frequently disrupts the physician’s conversation with the parents. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This teenager shows overly disruptive behavior toward figures of authority.
learning_objective: Recognize oppositional defiant disorder (ODD).

answers.explanation_why: Reactive attachment disorder does not result in temper tantrums or disruptive behavior. Instead, it is characterized by a consistent pattern of inhibited, emotionally withdrawn behavior toward caregivers or peers and a flat affect. Children with reactive attachment disorder usually have a history of parental neglect or foster care, which is not the case here. Moreover, a diagnosis of reactive attachment disorder cannot be made unless the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 5 years.

Conduct disorder is common during adolescence and may present with temper tantrums and disruptive behavior at home and school. However, patients with conduct disorder also have repetitive and persistent behavior that violates the basic rights of others and important age-appropriate societal norms, e.g., deceitfulness, stealing, property destruction, and violence, which is not present in this patient.

Patients with a disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) have recurrent temper tantrums both at home and at school. However, patients with DMDD are persistently angry or irritable in between these outbursts, which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, a diagnosis of DMDD cannot be made unless the symptoms have been ongoing for ≥ 12 months and the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 10 years.

Patients with antisocial personality disorder are impulsive, violent, and deceitful. They remorselessly disregard the basic rights of others. Such behavior is not present in this patient. Moreover, a diagnosis of antisocial personality disorder cannot be made until the person is 18 years of age.

Patients with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) are often described as “uncooperative” and “disruptive” by their teachers because they have difficulty remaining seated, quietly engaging in activities, and not interrupting other students in their activities. Difficulties sustaining attention can lead to an increased rate of mistakes and a deterioration of academic performance. However, unlike this child who defiantly refuses to answer questions, children with ADHD have difficulties controlling their impulse to talk and tend to answer out of turn. Moreover, temper tantrums and insulting behavior are not typical features of ADHD and the diagnosis of the condition can only be made if the onset of symptoms occurs before the age of 12 years.

Disruptive behavior and occasional temper tantrums can be a part of normal adolescent development. However, such behavior is considered pathological when it is frequent, persistent, and impairs the functioning of the individual and of others (e.g., peers, teachers, parents).

This patient's irritable mood, deliberately annoying peers, and defiant behavior toward authority figures without serious violation of social norms are consistent with oppositional defiant disorder (ODD). The frequency of this behavior, more than once per week, goes beyond what is normative for children of her age. Furthermore, the ≥ 6-month duration of symptoms fulfills the diagnostic criteria for ODD.

Individuals with ODD are negatively impacted in numerous areas important for normal functioning (e.g., social, educational, occupational), and the hostility they express is toward individuals within their immediate social circle (e.g., family members, peers, work colleagues, teachers). Therefore, peer group support and peer-mediated interventions, alongside psychotherapy, parent management training, and social-skills programs, are pivotal in treating ODD.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of teacher complaints regarding his poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention when assigned school-related tasks, does not follow the teachers' instructions, and makes careless mistakes in his homework. He often blurts out answers in class and has difficulty adhering to the rules during soccer practice. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at school. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of teacher complaints regarding his poor performance at school for the past 8 months. He has difficulty sustaining attention when assigned school-related tasks, does not follow the teachers' instructions, and makes careless mistakes in his homework. He often blurts out answers in class and has difficulty adhering to the rules during soccer practice. His mother reports that he is easily distracted when she speaks with him and that he often forgets his books at school. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on the appropriate first-line therapy. This boy is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
hint: This patient's symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity present in more than one setting (at home, in school, soccer practice), onset of symptoms before 12 years of age, and duration of symptoms for ≥ 6 months fulfill the diagnostic criteria for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is one of the most commonly used first-line medications.
learning_objective: Recognize attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and recall the side effects of methylphenidate.

answers.explanation_why: A prolonged QT interval can be caused by antiarrhythmic drugs (e.g., amiodarone), antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol), antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline), phenothiazines, and first-generation antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine). While the medication used for this patient's condition may induce tachycardia, it is not associated with a prolonged QT interval.

Serotonin syndrome is a condition caused by intake of serotonergic drugs (e.g., SSRIs). While it may present with some symptoms similar to the adverse effects caused by the medication given to this boy, serotonergic drugs are not indicated in the treatment of his condition.

Common medications that increase appetite or reduce metabolism and lead to weight gain include antipsychotics and antidepressants, which are not indicated in the treatment of the patient's condition. The medication he is receiving typically reduces appetite and can lead to weight loss.

Medications that may impair liver function and lead to an elevation of transaminases include acetaminophen, statins, and some anticonvulsants (e.g., valproate) and antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin). The medication this patient is receiving is not known to impair liver function.

Decreased perspiration is an adverse effect of anticholinergics (antimuscarinic agents) which are used to suppress functions of the parasympathetic nervous system (e.g., in the treatment of asthma, urinary incontinence). The first-line treatment given for this boy's condition typically has a sympathomimetic effect and increases perspiration.

This boy is most likely being treated with methylphenidate, which is first-line pharmacotherapy for ADHD. Methylphenidate has sympathomimetic activity and improves concentration, cognition, and short-term memory. Common adverse sympathomimetic effects include elevated arterial blood pressure, tachycardia, sweating, insomnia, decreased seizure threshold, and a reduced appetite/stunted growth.

question_text: Two days after undergoing hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 78-year-old man is found agitated and confused in his room. The patient points at one corner of the room and says, “There is a burglar, doctor!” Closer inspection reveals that the patient is pointing to his bathrobe, which is hanging on the wall. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include insulin and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a nontender, nonerythematous midline abdominal wound. On mental status examination, the patient is agitated and oriented only to person. Which of the following best describes this patient's perception?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing hemicolectomy for colon cancer, a 78-year-old man is found agitated and confused in his room. The patient points at one corner of the room and says, “There is a burglar, doctor!” Closer inspection reveals that the patient is pointing to his bathrobe, which is hanging on the wall. The patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include insulin and hydrochlorothiazide. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a nontender, nonerythematous midline abdominal wound. On mental status examination, the patient is agitated and oriented only to person. Which of the following best describes this patient's perception?
hint: This patient's misinterpretation of a real external stimuli is a common symptom of delirium.
learning_objective: Recognize an illusion in the context of delirium.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals displaying external attribution attempt to establish a cause for their feelings. This delirious patient is not attempting to establish a cause for his observation or his agitation but merely stating what he has perceived.

An illusion is a perceptual abnormality, in which an actual external stimulus is misinterpreted. This patient had a visual illusion because he saw the bathrobe and perceived it to be a burglar. This patient's disturbance of sensory perception is likely due to postoperative delirium, to which older patients are particularly susceptible.

A labile affect is characterized by excessive displays of emotion, emotions that are not congruent with a situation or the individual's mood, or a rapid change in the individual's emotions. This patient's affect is congruent with his perceived situation (agitation after suspecting the presence of a burglar) and does not change rapidly.

A delusion is a fixed, false belief that does not stem from customs, culture, or religion, and is maintained despite proof to the contrary (e.g., a patient insisting that they can fly, a patient insisting that they have won the lottery when this is not the case). This patient has a disturbance of sensory perception (not a delusion) when he perceives the bathrobe to be a burglar.

Loose association refers to the presentation of multiple ideas without a logical connection or flow between them. This patient has clearly stated his sensory perception (i.e., the bathrobe perceived as a burglar) and has not changed the topic.

This patient most likely suffers from postoperative delirium, which can cause visual hallucinations. Hallucinations are, however, disturbances of sensory perceptions that occur in the absence of external stimuli. In this patient, the disturbance of sensory perception occurs in the presence of an external visual stimulus (i.e., the bathrobe).
