question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking his legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of 2 episodes of screaming in the night over the past week. The parents report that their son woke up suddenly screaming, crying, and aggressively kicking his legs around both times. The episodes lasted several minutes and were accompanied by sweating and fast breathing. The parents state that they were unable to stop the episodes and that their son simply went back to sleep when the episodes were over. The patient cannot recall any details of these incidents. He has a history of obstructive sleep apnea. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize sleep terror disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Insomnia disorder is characterized by problems initiating and/or maintaining sleep, or waking up very early and being unable to return to sleep; symptoms occur ≥ 3 days/week for ≥ 3 months. However, the fearful incomplete arousal from sleep affecting this child is not a feature of insomnia disorder.

Delayed sleep phase disorder is a type of circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorder in which the patient is unable to fall asleep and awake at conventional sleep times (delay is usually > 2 hours), although the quality and duration of sleep may be normal (e.g., patient sleeps from 02:00 AM–10:00 AM). This condition is more common in adolescents than young children and the abrupt, fearful incomplete arousal from sleep that this child presents with is not seen in delayed sleep phase disorder.

Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is characterized by an urge to move the legs, especially at night when either awake or asleep. RLS is uncommon in young children, however, and does not cause the other features seen in this child.

Sleep terror disorder is a type of parasomnia in which children present with abrupt, incomplete arousal from sleep, screaming, crying, and/or trying to escape from an unseen threat. It also typically involves sympathetic hyperactivity (mydriasis, sweating, tachycardia, tachypnea), unresponsiveness to efforts at calming, and no recollection of the event on waking. The condition is usually self-limited. Sharp/potentially harmful objects should be kept away from the bedroom of the patient. Benzodiazepines may be helpful in refractory cases.

Nightmare disorder is a type of parasomnia that occurs in rapid eye movement (REM) sleep and is typically seen in adults. In contrast to this child, patients with nightmare disorder remember the dream vividly and can be easily roused during a nightmare episode. Vocalizations such as screaming or crying are not common in nightmare disorder (because of REM sleep-induced skeletal muscle tone loss).

Sleepwalking disorder is a type of parasomnia that occurs in NREM sleep and is typically seen in young children. This condition is associated with obstructive sleep apnea, and the patient often cannot remember the episode once fully awake. Also, it is difficult to wake up a patient during an episode. However, patients with sleepwalking disorder often have a blank stare during the episode of incomplete arousal from sleepwalking and are not agitated/distressed. For this reason, it is unlikely that this child has sleepwalking disorder.

question_text: A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He recently quit the school's football team after missing many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them but admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation because of loss of appetite, sleeplessness, and extreme irritability for the past 3 weeks. He recently quit the school's football team after missing many practices. He has also been avoiding his family and friends because he is not in the mood to see them but admits that he is lonely. He has not left his room for 2 days, which prompted his father to bring him to the physician. He has no medical conditions and does not take any medications. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. While the father is in the waiting room, mental status examination is conducted, which shows a constricted affect. Cognition is intact. He says that he would be better off dead and refuses to be treated. He says he wants to use his father's licensed firearm to “end his misery” over the weekend when his parents are at church. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient poses an immediate risk to himself, given his suicidal ideation with intent, plan, and access to firearms.
learning_objective: Recognize imminent suicide risk, and choose the most appropriate management for patient safety.

answers.content: Involuntary hospitalization after informing the parents
answers.explanation_why: This patient is an immediate threat to himself and requires hospitalization (even against his will) to prevent the completion of suicide. Although it varies from state to state, parental consent may not be required even though he is a minor, however, they should be notified of the hospitalization.

answers.content: Agree to his wish for no further treatment
answers.explanation_why: Patients who intend to immediately harm themselves do not have the right to decline medical therapy and can be provided with medical therapy against their will. It would be inappropriate to agree to this patient's wish for no further treatment.

answers.content: Reassure the patient that he will feel better
answers.explanation_why: Mere reassurance would be inappropriate for a patient who poses significant risk to himself.

This patient may benefit from an SSRI, such as paroxetine, in the near future. However, it may take patients on SSRIs 4–6 weeks to notice any significant improvements. Since this patient poses an immediate risk to himself, he requires more urgent management.

This patient may benefit from a mood stabilizer such as lithium in the near future. However, it can take several weeks for patients to notice any significant improvements. Since there is an immediate risk this patient may commit an act of self-harm, he requires more urgent management.

Although this patient may benefit from psychotherapy, he is at immediate risk of completing suicide upon leaving the physician's office. He therefore requires more intensive care than would be provided with outpatient management.

question_text: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a change in behavior. The mother reports that over the past 6 months, her daughter has had frequent mood swings. Sometimes, she is irritable for several days and loses her temper easily. In between these episodes, she behaves normally, spends time with her friends, and participates in gymnastics training twice a week. Her mother has also noticed that her daughter needs more time than usual to get ready for school. Sometimes, she puts on an excessive amount of make-up. One month ago, her teacher informed the parents that their daughter had skipped school and was seen at the local mall with one of her classmates instead. The patient reports that she often feels tired, especially when she has to wake up early for school. On the weekends, she sleeps until 1 pm. Menses have occurred at 15- to 45-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years; they are not associated with abdominal discomfort or functional impairment. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
content_preview: A previously healthy 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a change in behavior. The mother reports that over the past 6 months, her daughter has had frequent mood swings. Sometimes, she is irritable for several days and loses her temper easily. In between these episodes, she behaves normally, spends time with her friends, and participates in gymnastics training twice a week. Her mother has also noticed that her daughter needs more time than usual to get ready for school. Sometimes, she puts on an excessive amount of make-up. One month ago, her teacher informed the parents that their daughter had skipped school and was seen at the local mall with one of her classmates instead. The patient reports that she often feels tired, especially when she has to wake up early for school. On the weekends, she sleeps until 1 pm. Menses have occurred at 15- to 45-day intervals since menarche at the age of 12 years; they are not associated with abdominal discomfort or functional impairment. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's behavior?
hint: The patient's age and lack of functional impairment are important points worth noting.
learning_objective: Recognize normal adolescent behavior.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with borderline personality disorder can present with affective instability due to a marked reactivity of mood (e.g., intense episodic irritability usually lasting a few hours–days). However, affected individuals tend to have unstable relationships, display impulsivity, and recurrent suicidal gestures or self-mutilating behavior, all of which are inconsistent with this adolescent girl's presentation. Moreover, borderline personality disorder typically begins in early adulthood, not adolescence.

Puberty is accompanied by several cognitive, physical, and psychosocial changes. In the early stages of adolescence (onset of puberty 9–14 years in boys and 8–13 years in girls), individuals can experience negative feelings about their self-image, largely due to changes in their bodies and/or social pressure. Irritability (e.g., losing one's temper), mood swings, hypersomnia, fatigue, and infrequently skipping school, all of which are seen in this 13-year-old adolescent, are considered normal as long as they do not cause significant distress or functional impairment.

Patients with oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) can also present with irritable mood and loss of temper. However, the irritability associated with ODD is typically chronic (nonepisodic) and affected individuals often show argumentative, vindictive, and defiant behavior towards authority figures such as parents or teachers.

Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder (DMDD) can manifest with mood swings, irritability, and loss of temper. Symptoms of DMDD are much more severe than the symptoms in this patient, must begin before the age of 10 years, and include extreme irritability, anger, and severe recurrent outbursts of temper for ≥ 12 months without interruption > 3 months. All of these criteria are absent in this patient.

Pediatric patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) may also present with fatigue, hypersomnia, and irritability. In children, classic symptoms of MDD (e.g., depressed mood, loss of energy) may be less marked but the diagnosis of MDD requires that symptoms be present for at least two consecutive weeks, whereas this adolescent girl's behavior is episodic. She also behaves normally, is active and social, all of which are atypical for MDD.

Premenstrual syndrome can manifest with irritability, fatigue, and mood swings. However, these symptoms typically only occur before menstruation. According to the DSM-V, symptoms must have been present in most menstrual cycles of the previous year and must be associated with significant distress or interference with usual activities (e.g., work, school, social life). This adolescent girl does not demonstrate symptoms that meet the criteria for premenstrual syndrome.

Bipolar disorder in adolescent patients often manifests with irritability, and ongoing fluctuating mixed and depressive symptoms, which shift rapidly over hours or even minutes. However, this patient is missing further symptoms of hypomania or mania, such as euphoria, grandiose ideation, rapid, disorganized thinking and speech, and risky behavior.

Body dysmorphic disorder often includes camouflaging of disliked body parts. However, it typically also involves a preoccupation with a specific aspect of one's physical appearance, self-injurious behavior, and social withdrawal, all of which are not present in this patient.

question_text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she has been increasingly reluctant to speak at school over the past 4 months. Her teachers complain that she does not answer their questions and it is affecting her academic performance. She was born at 35 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. Previous well-child examinations have been normal. Her older brother was diagnosed with a learning disability 4 years ago. She is at 65^th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She follows commands. She avoids answering questions directly and instead whispers her answers to her mother, who then mediates between the doctor and her daughter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because she has been increasingly reluctant to speak at school over the past 4 months. Her teachers complain that she does not answer their questions and it is affecting her academic performance. She was born at 35 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia. Previous well-child examinations have been normal. Her older brother was diagnosed with a learning disability 4 years ago. She is at 65th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She follows commands. She avoids answering questions directly and instead whispers her answers to her mother, who then mediates between the doctor and her daughter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The previous well-child examinations have been unremarkable and she appears to be able to communicate well with her mother.
learning_objective: Recognize selective mutism.

answers.explanation_why: Reactive attachment disorder occurs in children with a history of neglect or abuse and typically manifests before 5 years of age. Affected children show a consistently withdrawn behavior toward caregivers, express minimal emotion toward others, and do not seek comfort when distressed. However, all previous well-child examinations were normal with no signs of abuse or neglect, and this girl has a normal relationship with her mother.

Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) manifests with persistent impairment in communication and social interaction, as well as restricted, stereotyped patterns of behavior, interests, and activities. It is particularly common in boys and manifests in early childhood. While children with ASD may also be reluctant to speak, it is unlikely in a school-aged girl with no history of current or previous abnormal behavior consistent with the diagnosis.

Social anxiety disorder is characterized by fear of being exposed to judgment or rejection from others in a social setting (e.g., at parties, public speaking). Affected children may refuse to speak in a public situation, stay close to their parents, or feel uncomfortable outside of their home. Since this girl shows no pronounced reluctance or fear of going to school, for instance, social anxiety disorder is unlikely.

This child's behavior is consistent with a diagnosis of selective mutism, a condition in which a child consistently refuses to speak when expected to (e.g., when asked a question in school) although their communication skills are not impaired. This behavior typically has a negative impact on normal life (e.g., academic performance) and is not exhibited in settings in which the child feels comfortable and safe (e.g., talking to family members or friends).

Children with social communication disorder present at an early age with difficulties in both verbal and nonverbal communication, such as adapting to social settings (e.g., being quiet during a performance) and using communication methods adequately (e.g., body language, eye contact). Since this girl has only recently been unwilling to speak but overall shows appropriate communication skills, social communication disorder can be ruled out.

Rett syndrome is an X-linked congenital disorder that almost exclusively affects girls and manifests with a progressive loss of cognitive functions, intelligence, and acquired abilities (e.g., language skills) in children who were previously developing normally. Since this child shows no signs of developmental regression and can communicate normally with her mother, Rett syndrome can be ruled out.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because she thinks that her “right wrist is broken.” She says that she has severe pain and that “the bone is sticking out.” She has not had any trauma to the wrist. Her medical records indicate that she was diagnosed with schizophrenia 2 years ago and treated with olanzapine; she has not filled any prescriptions over the past 4 months. Three weeks ago, she stopped going to work because she “did not feel like getting up” in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right wrist shows no visible injury; there is no warmth, swelling, or erythema. Range of motion is limited by pain. On mental status examination, she has a flat affect. Her speech is pressured and she frequently changes the topic. She has short- and long-term memory deficits. Attention and concentration are poor. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An x-ray of the wrist shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because she thinks that her “right wrist is broken.” She says that she has severe pain and that “the bone is sticking out.” She has not had any trauma to the wrist. Her medical records indicate that she was diagnosed with schizophrenia 2 years ago and treated with olanzapine; she has not filled any prescriptions over the past 4 months. Three weeks ago, she stopped going to work because she “did not feel like getting up” in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the right wrist shows no visible injury; there is no warmth, swelling, or erythema. Range of motion is limited by pain. On mental status examination, she has a flat affect. Her speech is pressured and she frequently changes the topic. She has short- and long-term memory deficits. Attention and concentration are poor. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Urine toxicology screening is negative. An x-ray of the wrist shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns?
hint: This patient presents with a somatic delusion (broken wrist), flattened affect, avolition, disorganized and pressured speech, poor concentration, and memory deficits, which suggests an acute psychotic episode. Her history of schizophrenia and discontinuation of antipsychotic treatment for the last four months further support this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate response to address a patient's somatic delusion.

answers.content: “I cannot see any injury of your wrist, and the physical exam and the x-ray don't show any injury. I imagine that feeling as if your wrist was broken may be very uncomfortable. Can you tell me more about what it feels like?”
answers.explanation_why: Establishing a therapeutic alliance is essential when taking care of patients with delusions. An empathy-based approach, which acknowledges the patient's emotional state, is an effective means of reinforcing the stability of therapeutic alliance and medication compliance. In addition, healthcare providers should avoid validating delusions or confronting patients about the delusional nature of their complaints.

answers.content: "I can imagine that you are uncomfortable. That certainly looks painful. Let's take care of this injury first and then we should talk about your problems getting up in the morning."
answers.explanation_why: Validating the patient's delusion would perpetuate the patient's beliefs rather than addressing the underlying cause (psychiatric disorder).

answers.content: “It seems as though you are having a schizophrenia relapse. If you don't follow my recommendations and take your medications, you will most likely have further and possibly more severe episodes.”
answers.explanation_why: Although the patient's symptoms are likely secondary to a schizophrenia relapse, this response does not address the patient's symptoms. Efforts to build a trusting relationship that will increase the chances of medication compliance should be pursued first.

answers.content: "You are clearly distressed. However, your tests do not suggest a physical problem that can be addressed with medications or surgery. I suggest that we meet and evaluate your symptoms on a regular basis."
answers.explanation_why: Meeting on a regular basis is indicated in patients with somatoform disorder. This patient's history of schizophrenia and medication nonadherence suggests that she is experiencing a somatic delusion secondary to a psychotic episode rather than a somatoform disorder. In the current setting, a statement that acknowledges her emotional state in an empathetic way is more appropriate.

answers.content: "Your physical examination findings and the x-ray cannot explain your symptoms, suggesting a psychological rather than a physical problem. I will prescribe olanzapine, which should relieve your symptoms."
answers.explanation_why: This response challenges the patient's subjective experience of symptoms and undermines her trust in her healthcare provider, thus hampering the establishment of a therapeutic relationship.

question_text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreasing academic performance at his college for the past 6 months. He reports a persistent fear of “catching germs” from his fellow students and of contracting a deadly disease. He finds it increasingly difficult to attend classes. He avoids handshakes and close contact with other people. He states that when he tries to think of something else, the fears “keep returning” and that he has to wash himself for at least an hour when he returns home after going outside. Afterwards he cleans the shower and has to apply disinfectant to his body and to the bathroom. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke cannabis but stopped one year ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. He appears anxious. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. In addition to starting an SSRI, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of decreasing academic performance at his college for the past 6 months. He reports a persistent fear of “catching germs” from his fellow students and of contracting a deadly disease. He finds it increasingly difficult to attend classes. He avoids handshakes and close contact with other people. He states that when he tries to think of something else, the fears “keep returning” and that he has to wash himself for at least an hour when he returns home after going outside. Afterwards he cleans the shower and has to apply disinfectant to his body and to the bathroom. He does not drink alcohol. He used to smoke cannabis but stopped one year ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. He appears anxious. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time. In addition to starting an SSRI, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has obsessions (thoughts about contamination) that lead to time-consuming compulsions of > 1 hour/day and result in significant academic impairment. This presentation is diagnostic of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).
learning_objective: Recognize obsessive-compulsive disorder, and choose the most appropriate non-pharmacological management.

answers.explanation_why: Supportive psychotherapy is a therapy approach that aims to improve self-esteem, resilience, and overall functioning in patients with anxiety disorders. Although individuals with OCD, such as this patient, often also have anxiety disorders and would benefit from supportive psychotherapy, it is not a first-line treatment.

Motivational interviewing, which is used in the treatment of substance use disorders and major depressive disorder, is a non-confrontational approach that aims to promote a sense of optimism and self-efficacy in patients. Since this patient no longer consumes cannabis and has no signs of depression, there is currently no indication for motivational interviewing.

This patient presents with OCD, for which first-line non-pharmacological management is cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT focuses on detecting and understanding negative or false thoughts and beliefs that lead to impairment of function as well as developing skills and strategies that help change the patient's behavior.

Psychodynamic psychotherapy is a treatment approach that focuses on analyzing an individual's past experiences to understand and treat current patterns of behavior and emotion. It is used primarily to treat patients with anxiety or panic disorder but is not a first-line treatment option for OCD.

Interpersonal therapy is a treatment approach indicated in patients with major depressive disorder that focuses on understanding problematic interpersonal relationships or life situations (e.g., recent move, change of jobs) that may either trigger or be caused by depression. While depressed individuals may also have intrusive negative thoughts (e.g., guilt, worthlessness), other key diagnostic features of depression (e.g., loss of interest) are not present in this patient.

Group therapy is a treatment approach in which a group of patients with similar disorders can share their thoughts, emotions, and experiences in an empathetic and supportive environment. Group therapy is most commonly used in the management of personality disorders and substance use disorders. While group therapy can be beneficial in most mental disorders, it is not a first-line treatment for OCD.

question_text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of progressive hair loss over the past 2 months. The parents report that they have noticed an increasing number of hairless patches on their daughter's head. The patient denies any itching. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient states that she has been feeling tense since her boyfriend broke up with her. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows irregular patches of hair loss and hair shafts of varying lengths, with no scaling or reddening of the scalp. Further examination shows poor growth of the eyebrows and eyelashes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for the evaluation of progressive hair loss over the past 2 months. The parents report that they have noticed an increasing number of hairless patches on their daughter's head. The patient denies any itching. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. The patient states that she has been feeling tense since her boyfriend broke up with her. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows irregular patches of hair loss and hair shafts of varying lengths, with no scaling or reddening of the scalp. Further examination shows poor growth of the eyebrows and eyelashes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This girl has hair loss on the scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes. These features are suggestive of a condition that is especially common in children and adolescents < 15 years of age following emotional, social, or academic stress.
learning_objective: Recognize trichotillomania.

answers.explanation_why: Androgenetic alopecia (AA) can occur at puberty in male individuals. In female individuals, however, it occurs at menopause, when estrogen levels decline and testosterone levels increase. AA may also occur in young women if an underlying hyperandrogenic condition exists (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, congenital adrenal hyperplasia, androgen-secreting ovarian tumors). In such cases, signs of virilization (e.g., hirsutism, acne, irregular menses) will be present in addition to the characteristic tiny vellus hairs in the areas of hair loss. AA does not cause hair loss of the eyebrows and eyelashes. The location and pattern of hair loss and the absence of signs of virilization in this patient make the diagnosis of AA unlikely.

Tinea capitis presents as patchy areas of hair loss affecting the scalp, eyebrows, and/or eyelashes, and is typically seen in young children. However, the scalp in the affected areas would be erythematous, scaly, and pruritic, which is not the case in this patient.

Scarring (cicatricial) alopecia is a rare type of circumscribed alopecia that can result in irregular patches of hair loss. Although the skin in the hair loss patches may also appear normal in scarring alopecia (since destruction and fibrosis of hair follicles occurs below the surface of the skin), more often than not there are signs of inflammation (e.g., redness, scaling, hyperpigmentation, hypopigmentation). The key differentiating feature is that the condition is not associated with hair of different lengths.

Telogen effluvium is an acute onset of diffuse hair loss often triggered by underlying endocrine disease (e.g., hypothyroidism, hypoparathyroidism), nutritional deficiency (e.g., hypervitaminosis A, zinc deficiency), certain drugs (e.g., anabolic steroids, antithyroid drugs, antimetabolites), and severe emotional stress. In telogen effluvium, the telogen (i.e., resting) phase of hair growth predominates, resulting in premature shedding of the resting hair and diffuse, nonscarring hair loss. Physical examination typically shows a diffuse decrease in hair density rather than the patchy hair loss with hair shafts of varying lengths seen here.

images.title: Telogen effluvium
images.description: Head of a patient 5 months after bariatric surgeryThe frontal (a) and the left side (b) of the scalp show a diffuse, nonscarring loss of hair. This appearance is caused by premature shedding of hair follicles in telogen phase (resting phase).Telogen effluvium can be caused, for example, by stress such as a surgery or severe febrile illness.

answers.explanation_why: In obsessive-compulsive disorder, the individual is driven by obsessive, intrusive thoughts (obsessions) to perform repetitive actions (compulsions), such as hand washing or counting (compulsions). The repetitive action serves to stop the obsessive thought. This patient presents with patchy hair loss but without obsessive thoughts, suggesting another diagnosis.

Alopecia areata can occasionally be triggered by stress (e.g., a recent breakup) and hair loss may simultaneously occur on the scalp, eyebrows, eyelashes, and other hair-bearing areas. However, physical examination in alopecia areata typically shows smooth, well-demarcated patches of hair loss. Moreover, short hairs which have a narrowing at the scalp end (i.e., exclamation point hairs) on the periphery of the hairless patch are a characteristic sign of alopecia areata. Irregular patches of hair loss with hair shafts of varying lengths is not an expected finding.

images.title: Alopecia areata
images.description: There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

answers.explanation_why: Individuals with trichotillomania (TTM) present with irregular patches of hair loss due to compulsive hair pulling. The scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes are the most commonly affected sites, and hair shafts may be of varying lengths. TTM is characterized by a compulsive urge to pull one's hair and consequent feelings of gratification and/or relief from hair pulling. Unlike in obsessive compulsive disorder, individuals with TTM do not experience obsessive or intrusive thoughts. TTM typically manifests in late childhood or early adolescence and is more common in female individuals. Diagnosis may be complicated as individuals with TTM are often reluctant to admit to the behavior. The treatment of choice for TTM is cognitive behavioral therapy.

images.title: Bald spots in trichotillomania
images.description: A pattern of uneven hair follicle distribution with bald spots is visible on this young woman's head.This pattern, together with a consistent history and physical examination, suggests trichotillomania.

question_text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her 17-year-old son because she believes she has been poisoned by her ex-husband. She reports that her coffee tasted “strange” this morning. After breakfast, she then saw a black car drive by the house, which she concludes must have been her ex-husband, who also drives a black car. She says that since the divorce 3 years ago, her ex-husband has been seeking revenge and thinks that he has installed cameras in her apartment to spy on her and their son. She has never seen any of these cameras but when she is alone in the apartment, she can sometimes hear them beeping and feel them recording her. The son also reports his mother's coffee mug smelled of bitter almonds, which he suspects was cyanide. He agrees with the mother's distrust towards his father and reports that he has also occasionally heard a camera beeping but has not been able to find any cameras yet. The mother's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.4. Toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with her 17-year-old son because she believes she has been poisoned by her ex-husband. She reports that her coffee tasted “strange” this morning. After breakfast, she then saw a black car drive by the house, which she concludes must have been her ex-husband, who also drives a black car. She says that since the divorce 3 years ago, her ex-husband has been seeking revenge and thinks that he has installed cameras in her apartment to spy on her and their son. She has never seen any of these cameras but when she is alone in the apartment, she can sometimes hear them beeping and feel them recording her. The son also reports his mother's coffee mug smelled of bitter almonds, which he suspects was cyanide. He agrees with the mother's distrust towards his father and reports that he has also occasionally heard a camera beeping but has not been able to find any cameras yet. The mother's vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows a pH of 7.4. Toxicology screening is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient presents with persecutory delusions as well as auditory hallucinations, which are symptoms of psychosis. The patient's son shows delusional symptoms in the context of a relationship with an individual with prominent delusions (formerly known as shared psychotic disorder).
learning_objective: Recognize delusional symptoms in the context of a relationship with an individual with delusions, and choose the appropriate initial management step.

answers.explanation_why: Ziprasidone is a first-line agent for the treatment of shared psychotic disorder. However, before beginning pharmacotherapy, the degree of delusion of mother and son should be assessed to determine whether pharmacotherapy is indicated and, if so, what agents are best suited for the treatment of these patients.

Fluphenazine is a very potent typical antipsychotic but is not a first-line drug in patients with shared psychotic disorder because of its possible extrapyramidal motor symptoms (e.g., dystonia). Before initiating pharmacotherapy, another measure is indicated here.

When delusional symptoms are suspected in an individual who has a relationship with someone with prominent delusions, they should be separated and assessed individually to determine the degree of delusion in each patient and evaluate the necessity for further interventions. Treatment includes individual psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy), second-generation antipsychotics for both patients and, if possible and/or necessary, spatial separation of the two.

While there are difficulties within this family (e.g., divorce, dysfunctional relationships), family therapy is not indicated here because it would likely reinforce the shared delusions rather than resolve them.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy can be helpful in treating patients with delusional disorders who refuse to take or cannot tolerate antipsychotics. It can help identify and engage the source of the delusions as well as manage the distress associated with them. However, before beginning any form of treatment, another measure is indicated here.

answers.content: Report the case to the police authorities
answers.explanation_why: The fact that toxicology screening was negative rules out cyanide poisoning and suggests that this woman's report was imaginary. While reports of abuse or threats should never be dismissed lightly, the rest of this patient's report supports the suspicion of delusion rather than indicating that an actual crime has been committed. This warrants assessment for a mental disorder before considering legal measures.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because he has been increasingly worried and stressed in recent weeks. He started a marketing job 7 months ago, which involves traveling between Washington and California several times a year. Six months ago, he was supposed to fly to Seattle, but he experienced nausea, palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath and was unable to board the plane, causing him great embarrassment. He had never been on a plane before; his parents died in a plane crash when he was a teenager. A week ago, he called in sick when he was supposed to go on a business trip. He worries that he will lose his job. He is otherwise well and has no history of serious illness. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is alert and cooperative. His speech is normal and his thought process is organized. His memory, attention, and concentration are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because he has been increasingly worried and stressed in recent weeks. He started a marketing job 7 months ago, which involves traveling between Washington and California several times a year. Six months ago, he was supposed to fly to Seattle, but he experienced nausea, palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath and was unable to board the plane, causing him great embarrassment. He had never been on a plane before; his parents died in a plane crash when he was a teenager. A week ago, he called in sick when he was supposed to go on a business trip. He worries that he will lose his job. He is otherwise well and has no history of serious illness. He takes no medications. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is alert and cooperative. His speech is normal and his thought process is organized. His memory, attention, and concentration are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has developed a specific phobia, aviophobia, a persistent (lasting ≥ 6 months) and intense fear of flying that is impairing his ability to perform necessary occupational tasks.
learning_objective: Choose the first-line treatment for specific phobias.

answers.explanation_why: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as paroxetine can be administered as bridge therapy for patients with specific phobias until first-line treatment is available or for patients who prefer this treatment. However, there is limited evidence that SSRIs effectively treat specific phobias and other medications and treatments are preferred for this condition.

Benzodiazepine-like medications such as zolpidem have a sedative effect and are mainly used to treat sleep disorders. Zolpidem is not an effective anxiolytic and is therefore not indicated for patients with specific phobias.

Benzodiazepines (e.g., alprazolam) have anxiolytic properties and can be administered as bridge therapy until first-line therapy for specific phobias is available or if patients prefer this alternative.

Beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) are used in the management of performance-only social anxiety disorder. Oral propranolol can be taken as needed 30–60 minutes prior to exposure to an anxiety-causing situation (e.g., singing, acting, public speaking). However, beta blockers are not effective in the management of specific phobias, such as this patient's aviophobia.

Psychodynamic psychotherapy aims to gain insight into a patient's unconscious in order to change undesirable patterns of behavior, feelings, and thoughts. This form of psychotherapy is used to treat anxiety disorders, depressive disorders, personality disorders, and anorexia nervosa but is not usually used in the treatment of specific phobias.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the first-line treatment for specific phobias. Patients with a specific phobia experience excessive and irrational fear in anticipation of, or during exposure to, a phobic stimulus. As a result, patients typically develop avoidance behaviors (e.g., this patient calls in sick to avoid air travel). CBT involves exposure therapy (e.g., in vivo, imaginative, virtual reality) and relaxation training to help patients develop cognitive and behavioral strategies to cope with fears and manage anxiety.

There is little evidence confirming the efficacy of pharmacotherapy for specific phobias. Benzodiazepines and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors can be administered as bridge therapy until CBT is available or if patients prefer medication.

question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping. She worries that the lack of sleep will ruin her career prospects as a model. She has been coming to the physician multiple times over the past year for minor problems. She is dressed very extravagantly and flirts with the receptionist. When she is asked to sit down in the waiting room, she begins to cry and says that no one listens to her. When she is called to the examination room, she moves close to the physician, repeatedly intends to touch his cheek, and makes inappropriate comments. She does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of difficulty sleeping. She worries that the lack of sleep will ruin her career prospects as a model. She has been coming to the physician multiple times over the past year for minor problems. She is dressed very extravagantly and flirts with the receptionist. When she is asked to sit down in the waiting room, she begins to cry and says that no one listens to her. When she is called to the examination room, she moves close to the physician, repeatedly intends to touch his cheek, and makes inappropriate comments. She does not have a history of self-harm or suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The patient has a personality disorder that has features that include inappropriately seductive behavior (e.g., flirting with the receptionist, inappropriate contact with the physician), emotional instability (e.g., shifting from flirting to crying and back to flirting), using her physical appearance to draw attention to herself (e.g., dressing extravagantly), and becoming uncomfortable when she is not the center of attention (e.g., coming to the doctor for multiple minor problems, claiming that no one listens to her).
learning_objective: Recognize histrionic personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with a dependent personality disorder may visit the physician frequently because they seek support and reassurance. However, they typically behave timidly and politely rather than flirtatiously and flamboyantly. In addition, patients with dependent personality disorder tend to have difficulty making everyday decisions and often require others to take over responsibilities for them, none of which is seen here.

Histrionic personality disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder can be made in patients with ≥ 5 of the following 8 criteria: inappropriate seductive behavior, the use of physical appearance to draw attention to oneself, discomfort when the individual is not the center of attention, emotional lability, theatricality, considering relationships to be more intimate than they actually are, impressionistic speech, and suggestibility (i.e., being easily influenced by others). This patient meets the first 6 criteria.

See “Overview of cluster B personality disorders” table.

Individuals with narcissistic personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking behavior and exaggerate the intimacy of their relationships with others. However, this attention-seeking behavior stems from a desire for praise and admiration rather than from a need for reassurance or approval. Patients with narcissistic personality disorder are more likely to react to criticism or rejection with rage rather than the emotional vulnerability seen here (e.g., crying). In addition, they exhibit other traits not seen in this patient, such as an excessive sense of self-importance, exaggeration of achievements, grandiosity, arrogance, a lack of empathy, and envy.

Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder may dress and behave eccentrically. However, they do not typically use physical appearance for the purpose of garnering attention. In addition, individuals with schizotypal personality disorder often display an impaired capacity and discomfort with close personal contact, rather than the excessive intimacy and flirtatiousness seen here. Moreover, they typically have superstitious beliefs and/or magical thinking.

Patients with borderline personality disorder may exhibit attention-seeking or manipulative behavior, rapidly shifting emotions, intense interpersonal relationships that alternate between extreme idealization and extreme devaluation, and a fear of abandonment. However, essential components of borderline personality disorder are a negative self-image and self-destructive behavior (e.g., self-harm, suicide attempts), which this patient does not have.

question_text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of severe pain over her neck, back, and shoulders for the past year. The pain worsens with exercise and lack of sleep. The use of over-the-counter analgesics has not resolved her symptoms. She also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees and tingling in her upper extremities that is worse in the morning. She takes escitalopram for generalized anxiety disorder and has a history of tension headaches that occur several times a month. Her maternal uncle has ankylosing spondylitis. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. Muscle strength is normal. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are within the reference ranges. X-rays of her cervical and lumbar spine show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent episodes of severe pain over her neck, back, and shoulders for the past year. The pain worsens with exercise and lack of sleep. The use of over-the-counter analgesics has not resolved her symptoms. She also has stiffness of the shoulders and knees and tingling in her upper extremities that is worse in the morning. She takes escitalopram for generalized anxiety disorder and has a history of tension headaches that occur several times a month. Her maternal uncle has ankylosing spondylitis. Examination shows marked tenderness over the posterior neck, bilateral mid trapezius, and medial aspect of the left knee. Muscle strength is normal. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and thyroid-stimulating hormone are within the reference ranges. X-rays of her cervical and lumbar spine show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: While patients with this condition often experience worsening pain with exercise, incremental aerobic activities have been shown to improve pain and level of function.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromyalgia.

answers.explanation_why: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PR) is an inflammatory rheumatic disease that typically manifests as symmetrical myalgia and stiffness mainly affecting the neck, back, shoulders, arms, and hips. The symptoms of PR are worse after periods of inactivity. However, PR is typically seen in individuals > 50 years, physical examination would show restricted range of motion, and laboratory analysis would show elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR), all of which are absent in this patient.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic diffuse musculoskeletal pain, paresthesia, stiffness, and/or widespread tenderness lasting > 3 months, and no signs of systemic inflammation or systemic disease on laboratory analysis (e.g., normal CBC, ESR, CRP, and TSH) or imaging. Other features that may be present in patients with fibromyalgia include unrefreshing sleep, cognitive dysfunction (“fibro fog”), and autonomic dysfunction. Fibromyalgia is most common in middle-aged women and is often associated with tension headaches or neuropsychiatric disorders (e.g., anxiety, depression).

Axial spondyloarthritis (ankylosing spondylitis) typically manifests with chronic myalgia and morning stiffness of the neck, back, shoulder, and hip in individuals < 40 years of age. As there is a genetic predisposition to ankylosing spondylitis (AS), this patient is at an increased risk of developing the condition. Inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), though often elevated in AS, may be normal even in active disease. However, the symptoms of AS characteristically improve with NSAIDs, examination would show some limitations in spine mobility, and imaging would show spinal abnormalities, such as loss of lumbar lordosis, vertebral body erosion, and sclerosis even in early stages of the disease.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disorder that more commonly affects women and typically manifests with chronic pain and morning stiffness of multiple joints. Although the peripheral skeleton (e.g., MCP, PIP, wrist, and ankle joints) is more commonly affected in RA, some patients will present with pain, predominantly of the neck, back, and hip. However, examination of the affected joints would show evidence of inflammation, such as erythema, warmth, and painful joint movements, while laboratory studies would show elevated inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP).

Polymyositis (PM) is an inflammatory myopathy that is most commonly seen in women between 40–60 years. PM primarily affects skeletal muscles and manifests as symmetrical proximal myopathy (symptoms include difficulty carrying weights, combing hair, climbing stairs, and getting up from a chair or bed), which is not seen in this patient. This patient's generalized myalgia and multiple tender points on examination may also occur in PM. However, examination would also show muscle weakness, and, in most cases, inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatine kinase) would be elevated. As this patient has normal muscle strength on examination, PM is unlikely.

Patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) may develop idiopathic somatic symptoms such as chronic myalgia. Furthermore, chronic pain is a risk factor for depression and generalized anxiety disorder and is a common comorbidity in patients with MDD. However, for this diagnosis, the diagnostic criteria for MDD, which include > 5 of the clinical features of MDD being present for at least 2 weeks, should be fulfilled. As this is not the case here, another diagnosis is more likely.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly affects women between 15–55 years of age. Although SLE can manifest with chronic myalgia and joint stiffness, most patients with SLE develop symmetrical, migratory, polyarticular arthritis, which is not seen here. In addition, investigations would show elevated inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP) and abnormalities in CBC (e.g., anemia, leukopenia, and/or thrombocytopenia).

question_text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her father because he has been worried about his daughter's strange behavior for the past 2 years. She does not have any friends, spends most of her time alone in her room, and does not feel comfortable around other people. She usually wears long cloaks and large, unusual hats. She wears her shoes to bed because she sleepwalks and claims “nargles” will try to steal them otherwise. Her father is concerned about her going to college because she was bullied in high school. At the end of last year, her father found her putting up posters around the school asking for her possessions to be returned, as the other students had been hiding them. The daughter seemed unconcerned though, saying that “it's all in good fun.” On mental status examination, she seems dreamy and avoids eye contact, but doesn't appear embarrassed about being addressed. Further evaluation discloses no disturbances in thought process, thought content, or perception. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her father because he has been worried about his daughter's strange behavior for the past 2 years. She does not have any friends, spends most of her time alone in her room, and does not feel comfortable around other people. She usually wears long cloaks and large, unusual hats. She wears her shoes to bed because she sleepwalks and claims “nargles” will try to steal them otherwise. Her father is concerned about her going to college because she was bullied in high school. At the end of last year, her father found her putting up posters around the school asking for her possessions to be returned, as the other students had been hiding them. The daughter seemed unconcerned though, saying that “it's all in good fun.” On mental status examination, she seems dreamy and avoids eye contact, but doesn't appear embarrassed about being addressed. Further evaluation discloses no disturbances in thought process, thought content, or perception. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: When asked about “nargles” she says “You can laugh! But people used to believe there were no such things as the Blibbering Humdinger or the Crumple-Horned Snorkack!”
learning_objective: Recognize schizotypal personality disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with social anxiety disorder experience anxiety in social situations, as is seen in this patient. However, in social anxiety disorder, anxiety is driven by an intense fear of embarrassment in social situations. Moreover, this patient's odd beliefs, magical thinking, and unusual clothing would not be explained by social anxiety disorder.

Schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It usually manifests with eccentric behavior, and affected individuals have odd beliefs or magical thinking that are inconsistent with cultural norms. This woman's social anxiety, inappropriate affect, and lack of close friends are also common features of this disorder.

Individuals with paranoid personality disorder are emotionally isolated and exhibit eccentric behavior, as seen in this patient. However, a key component of paranoid personality disorder is suspicion and distrust toward others. Although this woman is anxious around other people, she does not appear to be suspicious of them. Moreover, paranoid personality disorder is not typically associated with odd and/or magical thinking.

Patients with schizoid personality disorder present with eccentric behavior and have difficulty developing meaningful social relationships, as seen in this patient. Schizoid personality disorder is also characterized by a pervasive pattern of social withdrawal and a limited range of emotional expression. However, this patient's interest in paranormal phenomena, magical thinking, and eccentric clothing would not be explained by schizoid personality disorder.

Schizophrenia commonly presents with a prodrome of negative psychotic symptoms characterized by social withdrawal. Although this patient prefers to be alone and has odd beliefs, she does not meet the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia because she has no abnormalities of thought content (e.g., delusions), thought process (e.g., disorganized speech, loose associations), or perception (e.g., hallucinations).

question_text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her neighbors 30 minutes after they found her unconscious in her yard. Her neighbors report that she has been spending more time at home by herself because she recently lost her job. On arrival, she is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. She is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. She is able to stand on her toes. Her gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain and MR angiography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her neighbors 30 minutes after they found her unconscious in her yard. Her neighbors report that she has been spending more time at home by herself because she recently lost her job. On arrival, she is unable to provide a history. Her pulse is 76/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination shows significant weakness of the left upper and lower extremities. She is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine. She is able to stand on her toes. Her gait is unsteady. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ and symmetric. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. An MRI of the brain and MR angiography show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a neurologic deficit that manifests inconsistently; she is unable to plantarflex the ankle while supine but can stand on her toes.
learning_objective: Recognize functional neurological symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient has functional neurological symptom disorder (FND), a condition that manifests with neurologic symptoms that are inconsistent with neurologic disease. A characteristic finding in patients with FND is a neurologic deficit that manifests inconsistently during an examination, such as this patient's transient inability to plantarflex the ankles. This condition is more common among young women and typically develops after an acute stressor (e.g., trauma, interpersonal conflict). The diagnosis of FND requires thorough evaluation and ruling out of other possible diagnoses, such as a cerebrovascular accident in this patient with unilateral weakness and an unsteady gait after a loss of consciousness.

Other manifestations of FND include seizures, movement and speech disorders, sensory disturbances, and visual impairment.

Factitious disorder is a condition in which patients intentionally falsify manifestations of illness to assume the role of a sick patient (primary gain). Symptoms often manifest inconsistently during an examination (e.g., transient inability to plantarflex the toes). However, there is no indication that this patient is intentionally falsifying her symptoms or seeking primary gain. Patients usually also have a history of multiple health care visits, are evasive in providing history, and often refuse access to prior medical records.

Malingering involves the falsification of manifestations of illness to attain a secondary gain such as financial compensation or time off from work. Symptoms often manifest inconsistently during an examination (e.g., transient inability to plantarflex the toes). However, there is no indication that this patient is intentionally falsifying her symptoms or seeking a secondary gain. In addition, patients who malinger typically avoid extensive diagnostic procedures.

Somatic symptom disorder is a condition in which a patient has persistent somatic symptoms (e.g., headache, fatigue) that result in excessive thoughts and/or behaviors that disrupt daily life. This patient appears anxious and has weakness and an unsteady gait. However, a diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder requires symptoms to persist for ≥ 6 months.

Acute stress disorder is a condition that develops after a traumatic event and manifests with symptoms such as anxiety, intrusive thoughts, and negative mood that last between 3 days and 1 month. This condition does not cause somatic manifestations (e.g., weakness, unsteady gait).

Acute hemorrhagic stroke can cause unilateral weakness and an unsteady gait after a loss of consciousness. However, this condition manifests with abnormalities on neuroimaging (e.g., hyperdense lesions on CT scan), which are not seen in this patient.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of urinating up to 20 times each day. He has not had any dysuria and nocturia. He has been evaluated by several urologists but has not received a specific diagnosis despite extensive diagnostic testing. Various pharmacologic treatments have not improved his symptoms. He quit his job 1 year ago and stopped attending social events because his frequent urination has been disruptive. He spends most of his time at the library trying to learn what could be causing his symptoms. He would like to undergo a CT scan of his entire body to evaluate for cancer. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-year history of urinating up to 20 times each day. He has not had any dysuria and nocturia. He has been evaluated by several urologists but has not received a specific diagnosis despite extensive diagnostic testing. Various pharmacologic treatments have not improved his symptoms. He quit his job 1 year ago and stopped attending social events because his frequent urination has been disruptive. He spends most of his time at the library trying to learn what could be causing his symptoms. He would like to undergo a CT scan of his entire body to evaluate for cancer. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
hint: This man's frequent urination has caused him significant distress, and he spends a significant amount of time attending to his health concerns. Patients with this man's condition typically have a history of extensive diagnostic testing.
learning_objective: Recognize somatic symptom disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Illness anxiety disorder manifests with excessive health-related behaviors (e.g., frequent evaluation and extensive diagnostic testing) and preoccupation related to illness despite having no physical symptoms. This patient's frequent urination is a significant physical symptom.

Malingering is characterized by feigned symptoms or false claims of having an illness to obtain secondary gain (e.g., time off from work). Patients often present with vague complaints that do not conform to a known medical condition and insist on extensive medical evaluation. Though this patient requests additional testing, there is no clear attempt to obtain secondary gain in this case.

Atypical depression is diagnosed in individuals with depression, mood reactivity, and physical complaints without an identifiable somatic cause. An increased need for sleep and leaden paralysis are the characteristic features, but patients may also present with pain and generalized discomfort, none of which is seen in this patient. While his mental status examination showed a depressed mood and constricted affect, the abnormal preoccupation with his health is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

This patient has somatic symptom disorder, a condition characterized by ≥ 6 months of excessive thoughts, feelings, and/or behaviors related to a somatic symptom (e.g., heartburn, fatigue, headache, pain). His previous diagnostic workup did not reveal any known medical etiology of his frequent urination. Patients with this condition typically show a preoccupation with their health and develop significant distress, anxiety, and fear of severe illness.

Adjustment disorder manifests with a maladaptive emotional and/or behavior response that causes distress and impaired functioning within 3 months after the onset of a stressor. Though this patient experiences significant distress and impaired social functioning, he does not have a history of a specific stressful event.

Urinary tract infections can manifest with frequent urination but typically also cause other symptoms such as dysuria, urgency, and suprapubic pain. In addition, urinalysis of men with urinary tract infections almost always shows pyuria, but this man's laboratory evaluation showed no abnormalities.

question_text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks. During this period, he has also had difficulty sleeping. He adds that he has been “feeling down” most of the time since his girlfriend broke up with him 4 years ago. Since then, he has only had a few periods of time when he did not feel that way, but none of these lasted for more than a month. He reports having no problems with appetite, weight, or energy. He does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of persistent sadness and difficulty concentrating for the past 6 weeks. During this period, he has also had difficulty sleeping. He adds that he has been “feeling down” most of the time since his girlfriend broke up with him 4 years ago. Since then, he has only had a few periods of time when he did not feel that way, but none of these lasted for more than a month. He reports having no problems with appetite, weight, or energy. He does not use illicit drugs or alcohol. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and constricted affect. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's symptoms have been present for most days over the past 4 years without a symptom-free period > 2 consecutive months, providing a clue to the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia).

answers.explanation_why: Although this patient has been depressed for > 2 weeks, he only presents with four of the symptoms listed in the DSM-V criteria for major depressive disorder (depressed mood, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, and poor concentration). Diagnosis of major depressive disorder requires the presence of ≥ 5 criterion A symptoms (one of which must be anhedonia or depressed mood) as well as clinically significant distress or impaired functioning in important areas of life (e.g., work).

Depressive episodes in bipolar disorder can present with sadness, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, and poor concentration, as seen in this patient. However, the diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires the presence of at least one manic episode or hypomanic episode, which this patient has not had.

Depressive symptoms in cyclothymic disorder can present with sadness, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, and poor concentration, as seen in this patient. Diagnostic criteria for cyclothymic disorder include mood swings with distinct periods of depressive symptoms and distinct periods of manic or hypomanic symptoms for ≥ 2 years (or ≥ 1 year in the case of children), as well as symptom-free periods that do not exceed 2 months. Although this patient fulfills the second criterion, he lacks a history of distinct, alternating periods of depression and mania/hypomania. In addition, the diagnosis requires that the patient's condition cannot be better explained by bipolar disorder, major depressive episode, or hypomanic episode/manic episode.

This patient presents with a depressed mood, difficulty sleeping, and poor concentration, which is causing psychosocial impairment. These symptoms have been present for more days than not for the past 4 years in the absence of substance use, and the patient was not asymptomatic for > 2 consecutive months during this time. Accordingly, he meets the criteria for persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia). He would likely benefit from treatment with an SSRI and/or psychotherapy.

images.title: Symptom-duration criteria for the diagnosis of mood disorders

answers.explanation_why: Adjustment disorder with depressed mood can manifest with sadness, anhedonia, sleep disturbances, and poor concentration, all of which are seen in this patient. However, the diagnosis requires the development of depressive symptoms within 3 months of a clear psychosocial stressor and resolution of symptoms within 6 months after termination of the stressor. This patient has had symptoms for the past 4 years, and there is no evidence to suggest that his mood is a reaction to a recent stressor.

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department with palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath that began 10 minutes ago. He says, “Please help me, I don't want to die.” He has experienced several similar episodes over the past 2 months, which occurred without warning in situations including open spaces or crowds and resolved gradually after 10 to 20 minutes. He has been staying at home as much as possible out of fear of triggering another episode. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He drinks 2 bottles of beer daily. He appears anxious and has a flushed face. His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department with palpitations, sweating, and shortness of breath that began 10 minutes ago. He says, “Please help me, I don't want to die.” He has experienced several similar episodes over the past 2 months, which occurred without warning in situations including open spaces or crowds and resolved gradually after 10 to 20 minutes. He has been staying at home as much as possible out of fear of triggering another episode. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He drinks 2 bottles of beer daily. He appears anxious and has a flushed face. His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?
hint: This patient's history of 10–20 minute episodes of palpitations, sweating, shortness of breath, and fear of dying that occur in both crowded and open spaces is suggestive of panic attacks. The presence of recurrent panic attacks for ≥ 1 month with behavior modification due to fear of subsequent episodes is consistent with panic disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize panic disorder, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment for an acute panic attack.

answers.explanation_why: Oral propranolol, a nonselective beta blocker, is an appropriate treatment for performance-only social anxiety disorder, which may manifest with palpitations and sweating. This patient's fear, however, is not restricted to performing in front of others (e.g., public speaking), which is characteristic of this disorder.

Intravenous thiamine (vitamin B_1) is part of the initial management of suspected alcohol withdrawal to prevent or treat Wernicke encephalopathy. This patient drinks 2 bottles of beer daily and anxiety, palpitations, and sweating may be symptoms of minor alcohol withdrawal. However, symptoms of minor alcohol withdrawal typically last 24–48 hours rather than 10–20 minutes.

Plasma metanephrines are the most appropriate initial diagnostic study for suspected pheochromocytoma, which may cause palpitations, sweating, and anxiety. Other features of this tumor include headaches, pallor, and episodic hypertension, none of which are seen here. Furthermore, fear of dying and change in behavior because of fear of triggering another episode are not typical features of pheochromocytoma.

Oral buspirone is a long-term treatment option for individuals with anxiety disorder (e.g., generalized anxiety disorder). Although this patient has some anxiety-related symptoms (e.g., palpitations and sweating), generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by ≥ 6 months of excessive and persistent worry that is nonspecific or revolves around certain themes (e.g., work, health, money), not anticipatory fear of panic attacks.

An oral, short-acting benzodiazepine (e.g., alprazolam) is the most appropriate initial treatment option for the management of suspected acute panic attacks. Pharmacotherapy should be considered if the attacks are severe and/or nonpharmacological interventions (e.g., reassurance, relaxation techniques) fail. While benzodiazepines are useful for the short-term management of panic attacks, they should not be used long-term because of the high potential for addiction and the development of tolerance. For long-term management, cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment, followed by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) if pharmacotherapy is necessary.

A cardiac stress test may be an appropriate initial step in the evaluation of suspected episodes of angina pectoris. Based on this patient's age and lack of risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., smoking, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), he has a very low pretest probability for coronary artery disease.

Oral venlafaxine is an appropriate long-term pharmacotherapy for panic disorder. However, it typically takes weeks before oral venlafaxine has an effect, which is why it is not useful in acute settings.

Long-term ECG monitoring (Holter monitoring) is the most appropriate next step in evaluating a suspected arrhythmia. Palpitations and shortness of breath are possible features of an arrhythmia. However, this patient's cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and ECG findings show sinus tachycardia. Furthermore, fear of dying and change in behavior because of fear of triggering another episode, which is seen in this patient, are not typical features of arrhythmia.
