question_text: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of persistent sadness for the past 2 months. During this period, she also has had difficulty sleeping and an increased appetite. She had similar episodes that occurred 2 years ago and 9 months ago that each lasted for 4 months. Between these episodes, she reported feeling very energetic and rested after 3 hours of sleep. She often went for long periods of time without eating. She works as a stock market trader and received a promotion 5 months ago. She regularly attends yoga classes on the weekends with her friends. On mental status examination, she has a blunted affect. She denies suicidal thoughts and illicit drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her husband because of persistent sadness for the past 2 months. During this period, she also has had difficulty sleeping and an increased appetite. She had similar episodes that occurred 2 years ago and 9 months ago that each lasted for 4 months. Between these episodes, she reported feeling very energetic and rested after 3 hours of sleep. She often went for long periods of time without eating. She works as a stock market trader and received a promotion 5 months ago. She regularly attends yoga classes on the weekends with her friends. On mental status examination, she has a blunted affect. She denies suicidal thoughts and illicit drug use. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's depressive and hypomanic symptoms have not resulted in marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or required hospitalization.
learning_objective: Recognize cyclothymic disorder.

answers.content: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern
answers.explanation_why: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern is characterized by ≥ 2 major depressive episodes over ≥ 2 years that are associated with a particular time of the year (e.g., the winter season). However, this patient's depressive symptoms do not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode, and they are not associated with a particular season. In addition, the hypomanic symptoms seen in this patient are uncharacteristic of major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern.

Bipolar II disorder is characterized by ≥ 1 hypomanic episode and ≥ 1 major depressive episode. Although this patient has both hypomanic and depressive symptoms, her symptoms do not fulfill the diagnostic criteria for either a hypomanic episode (i.e., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms) or a major depressive episode. Moreover, the chronicity of her symptoms indicates a different diagnosis.

Persistent depressive disorder (PDD) is a depressive disorder characterized by a depressed mood and ≥ 2 clinical features of PDD (feelings of hopelessness, low self-esteem, insomnia or hypersomnia, poor concentration or difficulty making decisions, fatigue, and an increase or decrease in appetite). These symptoms must be present during most of the day for the majority of the time over ≥ 2 years and cannot be attributable to substance use, bipolar disorder, psychotic disorders, or another medical condition. To meet the diagnostic criteria for PDD, there must be ≤ 2 consecutive months of a symptom-free period. This patient has had > 2 month periods without depressive symptoms. In addition, the hypomanic symptoms seen in this patient are uncharacteristic of PDD.

Cyclothymic disorder (cyclothymia) is characterized by distinct periods of depressive symptoms and distinct periods of hypomanic symptoms for ≥ 2 years (or ≥ 1 year for children). To meet the diagnostic criteria for cyclothymic disorder, there must be ≤ 2 consecutive months of a symptom-free period, and symptoms should not meet the diagnostic criteria for either a hypomanic episode (i.e., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms) or a major depressive episode (i.e., ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms).

Bipolar disorder with rapid cycling is characterized by ≥ 4 mood episodes within 1 year. Although this patient has had distinct episodes of hypomanic and depressive symptoms, her symptoms do not meet the diagnostic criteria for a mood episode (e.g., ≥ 3 hypomanic symptoms for a hypomanic episode, ≥ 5 SIGECAPS symptoms for a major depressive episode).

answers.content: Major depressive disorder with atypical features
answers.explanation_why: Major depressive disorder with atypical features is characterized by mood reactivity (i.e., transient improvement in mood in response to a positive event) and ≥ 2 symptoms of increased appetite or weight gain, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis, and long-standing interpersonal rejection sensitivity that results in occupational or social impairment. Although this patient has an increased appetite, she does not have other atypical features, and her symptoms do not meet the diagnostic criteria for a major depressive episode. In addition, the presence of hypomanic symptoms is uncharacteristic of major depressive disorder with atypical features.

question_text: A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of depressed mood and fatigue. During this time, she has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain. She reports trouble concentrating at her job as a preschool teacher and has missed work several times in recent weeks due to generalized fatigue. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years and is actively trying to quit smoking. A drug is prescribed that will treat the patient's mood disturbance and support smoking cessation. This patient should be counseled about which of the following possible side effects of this drug?
content_preview: A previously healthy 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of depressed mood and fatigue. During this time, she has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight gain. She reports trouble concentrating at her job as a preschool teacher and has missed work several times in recent weeks due to generalized fatigue. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years and is actively trying to quit smoking. A drug is prescribed that will treat the patient's mood disturbance and support smoking cessation. This patient should be counseled about which of the following possible side effects of this drug?
hint: Depressed mood, anhedonia, fatigue, and weight changes are consistent with major depressive disorder. Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant used to treat major depressive disorder and can help relieve cravings and withdrawal symptoms in individuals who are trying to quit smoking.
learning_objective: Recall the side effects of bupropion used for major depressive disorder and smoking cessation.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased libido is a common side effect of treatment with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and one of the most common reasons for discontinuation of SSRIs. Bupropion is commonly prescribed to patients experiencing decreased libido due to SSRI therapy, as it does not cause this side effect.
Tricyclic antidepressants can cause postural hypotension due to the off-target blockade of muscarinic receptors and alpha receptors. However, hypotension is not a side effect of bupropion.

Urinary retention is an anticholinergic side effect of tricyclic antidepressants such as amitriptyline. Bupropion does not have anticholinergic side effects and is not known to affect the urinary system.

Bupropion inhibits neuronal dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake. Reuptake inhibition not only increases the levels of these substances in the synapse (which is responsible for the drug's effect on mood and ability to alleviate nicotine cravings) but also in peripheral circulation. Bupropion can therefore cause stimulant effects such as tachycardia, insomnia, weight loss, and reduction in the seizure threshold. The risk of tachycardia is dose-related and higher doses of the drug can even predispose patients to cardiac arrhythmias.
QTc prolongation is a side effect of tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline). Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that is not associated with QTc prolongation.

Weight gain is not associated with bupropion use. Instead, weight loss is commonly observed after starting the drug and may even be a secondary benefit in patients with major depressive disorder and obesity. Other atypical antidepressants, especially mirtazapine, are much more commonly implicated in weight gain.

question_text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination required for his occupation as a school bus driver. He feels well and healthy. Upon questioning, he reports that he has smoked 2 joints of marijuana every night after work for the past year for recreational purposes. He typically smokes 5 joints or more on weekends. Which of the following responses by the physician is the most appropriate?
content_preview: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination required for his occupation as a school bus driver. He feels well and healthy. Upon questioning, he reports that he has smoked 2 joints of marijuana every night after work for the past year for recreational purposes. He typically smokes 5 joints or more on weekends. Which of the following responses by the physician is the most appropriate?
hint: There is no indication that this man is aware that his marijuana use is a problem.
learning_objective: Recognize the stages of behavioral change, and choose an appropriate motivational interviewing technique.

answers.content: "Let me know when you are ready to stop smoking marijuana. We can talk about specific strategies to help you quit at that time."
answers.explanation_why: This response inappropriately assumes that the patient is aware that his marijuana use is a problem and that he is unwilling to make a change, which corresponds to the contemplation stage of the transtheoretical model. At this stage, physicians should check in regularly with patients about their behavior and counsel that they can discuss strategies to modify their behavior at a time when the patient is more willing to make a change.

answers.content: "Have you ever experienced a situation in which you wished you smoked less marijuana?"
answers.explanation_why:
The transtheoretical model posits that health behavior change involves progress through several stages of change. This man, who does not seem to be aware that his marijuana use is a problem, is at the pre-contemplation stage. At this stage, physicians should ask open, probing, and nonjudgmental questions that explore the patient's perception of the situation.

Additional stages of the transtheoretical model include contemplation (aware of the problem without willingness to change), preparation (prepared to make a change), action (taking steps to change a behavior), and maintenance (behavioral changes are maintained).

images.title: Transtheoretical model of behavioral change
images.description:
– Precontemplation stage (*): The individual denies or is unaware there is a problem
– Contemplation stage: The individual is aware there is a problem but not willing to make a change
– Preparation stage: The individual is ready/preparing to make a change
– Action stage: The individual demonstrates a change in behavior
– Maintenance stage: The individual maintains the behavioral changes. This may be permanent, or they may relapse.
– Relapse: The behavioral changes are reversed. The cycle may restart.

answers.content: "When did you start being dependent on marijuana consumption?"
answers.explanation_why: This response inappropriately assumes that the patient is aware that his marijuana use is a problem. Though it may become important later to create a timeline of the patient's substance use disorder to better understand the problem, this step is premature. Making assumptions about the patient's perception of his situation may discourage him from being forthcoming about discussing the issue.

answers.content: "I think you should stop smoking marijuana. There are children's lives that you put at risk every day."
answers.explanation_why: This response inappropriately uses guilt and blame to address the patient's marijuana use, which may create a hostile environment that does not encourage a meaningful relationship between the physician and patient or encourage the patient to change his behavior. It is important to engage patients in a conversation using reflective and motivational listening techniques (e.g., nonjudgmental language).

answers.content: "We have a great program to help patients with substance use disorder issues. Let me give you more information about specific details."
answers.explanation_why: This response inappropriately assumes that the patient is aware that his marijuana use is a problem and that he is prepared to make a change, which corresponds to the preparation stage of the transtheoretical model. At this stage, physicians should provide information to patients about different strategies to modify their behavior.

answers.content: "You should stop smoking marijuana because it is not good for your health."
answers.explanation_why: This response inappropriately does not consider the patient's perception of his situation. The patient may be aware that smoking marijuana is not good for his health; he may choose to continue smoking for other reasons. Making assumptions about the patient's knowledge is patronizing and may discourage him from being forthcoming about discussing the issue.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to a psychotherapist for counseling because he was physically abused by his father. During the first therapy session, the patient recounts the numerous encounters that he had with his abuser. At the end of the session, the therapist, who lost her own son in a car accident when he was 15 years old, refuses to let the patient take the bus back alone to his custodial guardian's home. She offers to take him back in her own car instead, saying, “This way, I will rest assured that you have reached home safely”. The therapist's behavior can be best described as an instance of which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to a psychotherapist for counseling because he was physically abused by his father. During the first therapy session, the patient recounts the numerous encounters that he had with his abuser. At the end of the session, the therapist, who lost her own son in a car accident when he was 15 years old, refuses to let the patient take the bus back alone to his custodial guardian's home. She offers to take him back in her own car instead, saying, “This way, I will rest assured that you have reached home safely”. The therapist's behavior can be best described as an instance of which of the following?
hint: The psychotherapist is having difficulty maintaining her position of neutrality and seems to feel protective towards her patient.
learning_objective: Recognize the concept of countertransference in psychotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Displacement (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism that involves shifting negative feelings toward an event or person to a neutral, less threatening target. An example of displacement would be if the therapist had been reprimanded unfairly by her supervisor and shifted her frustrations to her husband. However, her loss of neutrality can better be attributed to another psychological mechanism.

Isolation of affect is an immature defense mechanism in which individuals detach themselves from strong thoughts/emotions toward a specific source. An example of isolation of affect would be if the therapist started talking about the death of her son without showing any emotions. However, the therapist's actions imply a loss of neutrality, which can be better attributed to another psychological mechanism.

Sublimation (psychiatry) is a mature defense mechanism in which an individual channels socially unacceptable desires into acceptable actions. An example of sublimation would be if the therapist sublimated jealousy toward her coworkers into performing better at work. However, the therapist's actions imply a loss of neutrality, which can be better attributed to another psychological mechanism.

Projection (psychiatry) is a defense mechanism in which an individual is in denial of certain feelings or desires and attributes them to another person. An example of projection would be if the therapist were in denial of her own guilt regarding the death of her son and instead projected the guilt onto her husband. The therapist's loss of neutrality can be better attributed to a different psychological mechanism.

Countertransference is a phenomenon in which a therapist projects feelings about important persons in their own life onto the patient. This therapist has likely transferred her feelings toward her deceased son to the patient. Her breaking of neutrality in the absence of an immediate need (e.g., impending harm to the patient) and in order to alleviate her own feelings of anxiety towards the patient's situation suggests countertransference. Awareness of countertransference is necessary to facilitate therapeutic work, as it allows the therapist to circumvent transference of their own insecurities onto the patient.

Identification (psychiatry) is an immature defense mechanism that involves individuals unconsciously copying characteristics or habits of an idealized person. An example of the therapist using this defense mechanism would be her taking on either external characteristics (e.g., wearing the same clothes, having the same haircut) or internal characteristics (e.g., behaviors, attitudes) of the patient. However, her loss of neutrality can better be attributed to another psychological mechanism.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, depressed mood, insomnia due to vivid dreams, and fatigue. Since yesterday, she has also had nausea and has noticed an unusual “electric shock-like” sensation on her skin. She has had major depression for 6 years and multiple sclerosis for 4 years. Her medications are natalizumab and paroxetine, which she stopped taking 1 week ago after having a positive pregnancy test. She appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows flat affect, gait instability, tremor, and muscle pain. Muscle strength is normal. An MRI of the brain shows multiple old periventricular white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of headache, depressed mood, insomnia due to vivid dreams, and fatigue. Since yesterday, she has also had nausea and has noticed an unusual “electric shock-like” sensation on her skin. She has had major depression for 6 years and multiple sclerosis for 4 years. Her medications are natalizumab and paroxetine, which she stopped taking 1 week ago after having a positive pregnancy test. She appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows flat affect, gait instability, tremor, and muscle pain. Muscle strength is normal. An MRI of the brain shows multiple old periventricular white matter lesions. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's current symptoms?
hint: This patient's symptoms are most likely related to her stopping her medications.
learning_objective: Recognize antidepressant discontinuation syndrome.

answers.explanation_why:
Abrupt cessation of antidepressant drugs without appropriate tapering, as seen here, can lead to adverse effects in as few as 1–4 days. This patient's presentation (i.e., headache, depressed mood, fatigue, insomnia, nausea, sensory disturbances, irritability, ataxia, tremor, and myalgia) is consistent with antidepressant discontinuation syndrome (ADS), a known side effect of sudden discontinuation of SSRIs. Paroxetine, in particular, is associated with an increased risk of ADS. The main clinical features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome can be remembered with the mnemonic FINISH: Flu-like symptoms, Insomnia, Nausea, Instability, Sensory disturbances, and Hyperarousal. Treatment consists of restarting antidepressant therapy at the original dose before beginning to taper slowly for at least 2–4 weeks.

Although exposure to SSRIs during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with a low risk of teratogenicity, some studies have suggested an increased risk of congenital heart defects related to the use of paroxetine. Nevertheless, the risks of untreated major depression in expectant mothers usually outweigh the potential risks of antidepressant therapy.

Symptoms of serotonin syndrome, which can be associated with SSRIs (e.g., paroxetine), include tremor, nausea, and ataxia, as seen in this patient. However, serotonin syndrome classically manifests with a triad of neuromuscular excitability (e.g., myoclonus, hyperreflexia), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, diaphoresis, hyperthermia, mydriasis), and altered mental status, none of which are present here. Moreover, this condition occurs in patients on ≥ 2 serotonergic drugs or those who switch from one serotonergic drug to another without prior tapering. This patient recently discontinued paroxetine without starting another serotonergic agent, essentially excluding this diagnosis.

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which can manifest with gait instability and behavioral changes, as seen here, almost exclusively develops in patients with severe immunosuppression. Treatment with natalizumab, the drug this patient has been using for multiple sclerosis, is a risk factor for PML. However, PML is associated with focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, aphasia, visual field deficits), seizures, and altered mental status; none of which are present in this patient. An MRI would show asymmetric, patchy, non-enhancing, multifocal white matter lesions without mass effect. This patient's MRI findings are more consistent with her previously diagnosed multiple sclerosis.

This patient with a history of major depressive disorder (MDD) presents with depressed mood, flat affect, fatigue, and insomnia shortly after cessation of antidepressant therapy with paroxetine, which might raise concern for an MDD relapse. However, she has only been experiencing these symptoms for 4 days, whereas the diagnosis of a major depressive episode requires the presence of ≥ 5 typical symptoms for at least 2 weeks. Moreover, symptoms occurring 3 days after discontinuation of treatment are very unlikely to be due to MDD relapse. Finally, this patient presents with neurological manifestations (tremor, ataxia), which are not associated with MDD.

This patient with a history of multiple sclerosis (MS) presents with a change in mental state (i.e., depressed mood), gait instability, and unusual electric shock-like sensations on her skin (potentially Lhermitte sign) shortly after cessation of natalizumab, raising concern of an MS relapse. However, she lacks additional symptoms of MS exacerbation, such as visual changes, motor weakness, and autonomic dysfunction (e.g., bladder disorder). Moreover, the absence of new periventricular white matter lesions on MRI makes an MS relapse unlikely. Finally, studies have shown that the time to clinical relapse after cessation of natalizumab is about 3–5 months (consistent with its natural course of elimination), not a couple of days.

This patient with major depressive disorder (MDD) presents with a 4-day history of irritability and insomnia, raising concern for a hypomanic episode with underlying bipolar II disorder. However, fatigue, a flat affect, and depressed mood, as seen here, would not be expected during a hypomanic episode; in contrast, symptoms such as increased goal-directed activity, psychomotor agitation, and talkativeness, as well as heightened self-esteem, are needed to fulfill the diagnostic criteria. Moreover, this patient presents with neurological symptoms (tremor, ataxia), which are not associated with bipolar disorders.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated for shortness of breath, palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness that developed 2 minutes after she was placed in a supine position for an MRI scan. The patient says that she cannot breathe and feels like she is dying. Two weeks ago, she was scheduled for an MRI of the pituitary gland because of a 4-month history of amenorrhea and bitemporal hemianopia. During the scan, the patient similarly reported dyspnea and a choking sensation. The procedure was stopped, and the symptoms resolved shortly after she was removed from the MRI scanner; the MRI scan was rescheduled for today. The patient has major depressive disorder well controlled with fluoxetine. Her mother has coronary artery disease. The patient is diaphoretic. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 145/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia; there is no evidence of ischemia or right heart strain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated for shortness of breath, palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness that developed 2 minutes after she was placed in a supine position for an MRI scan. The patient says that she cannot breathe and feels like she is dying. Two weeks ago, she was scheduled for an MRI of the pituitary gland because of a 4-month history of amenorrhea and bitemporal hemianopia. During the scan, the patient similarly reported dyspnea and a choking sensation. The procedure was stopped, and the symptoms resolved shortly after she was removed from the MRI scanner; the MRI scan was rescheduled for today. The patient has major depressive disorder well controlled with fluoxetine. Her mother has coronary artery disease. The patient is diaphoretic. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 145/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no other abnormalities. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia; there is no evidence of ischemia or right heart strain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: This patient presents with shortness of breath, dizziness, palpitations, chest pain, diaphoresis, and severe psychological distress within minutes of entering an MRI scanner. There are no signs of a life-threatening condition (e.g., myocardial infarction, anaphylaxis). These findings, combined with a history of a similar episode that resolved spontaneously, suggest a panic attack due to claustrophobia.
learning_objective: Recognize a panic attack, and choose the most appropriate acute pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), which can be used for the long-term treatment of anxiety disorders, including specific phobias (e.g., claustrophobia) not controlled by cognitive behavioral therapy. However, SSRIs often take several weeks before they achieve their full efficacy and are not appropriate for managing an acute panic attack.

Benzodiazepines with a rapid onset of action (e.g., lorazepam) can be used for the management of an acute panic attack (e.g., in the context of acute procedural anxiety). Although panic attacks often self-resolve after a few minutes, as was the case in this patient's prior episode, pharmacotherapy should be considered to relieve her current moderate to severe, persistent symptoms. Because this patient's panic attacks are most likely due to a specific phobia (i.e., claustrophobia), it is appropriate to consider administering a benzodiazepine prior to future procedures.

While benzodiazepines are useful for the short-term management of panic attacks, they should not be used for long-term management because of the high potential for addiction and the development of tolerance. For long-term management, cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment, followed by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors if pharmacotherapy is necessary.

Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is the first-line treatment for long-term management of anxiety disorders, including specific phobias such as claustrophobia. However, CBT is not appropriate in the acute setting.

Haloperidol is indicated for the management of acute or severe aggression and agitation. While these symptoms can occur in the setting of underlying psychiatric disorders, including major depressive disorder (MDD), this patient does not demonstrate acute or severe aggressive and agitated behavior, and her MDD is well controlled. Haloperidol is not indicated for the treatment of acute panic attacks or specific phobias.

Propranolol can be used in the management of performance-only social anxiety disorder (SAD), which can manifest with symptoms of anxiety (e.g., palpitations, diaphoresis). However, the symptoms in performance-only SAD are restricted to public speaking and/or performing in front of crowds. Although propranolol has been considered for the management of acute procedural anxiety, the clinical experience with beta-blockers is limited compared to other pharmacotherapies.
Biofeedback therapy can be considered for the long-term treatment of anxiety disorders. However, biofeedback therapy is not appropriate in the acute setting.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive muscle pain. The pain started in the shoulder muscles and then spread to the arms, back, and legs. She often feels stiff in the morning but does not have significant joint pain. She reports that she has had trouble sleeping because of the pain and cannot concentrate during the day. Medical history is remarkable for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. She appears tired. Examination shows tenderness in the arms and legs and along the axial skeleton. There is no joint swelling. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 13.4 g/dL, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 10 mm/h, and a creatine kinase concentration of 55 U/L. Results of other laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's history of chronic, widespread muscle tenderness, morning stiffness, fatigue, cognitive dysfunction (difficulty concentrating), and sleep disturbances, in conjunction with normal laboratory studies, suggests fibromyalgia (FM). FM mostly affects women between the second and fifth decade of life and is often associated with psychiatric disorders, such as depression.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromyalgia, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Electromyography (EMG) is used in the diagnosis of neurogenic and myopathic disorders, such as inflammatory myopathies, which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which EMG is not needed to establish the diagnosis.

Muscle biopsy is used in the diagnosis of inflammatory myopathies, such as polymyositis (PM) and dermatomyositis (DM), which manifest with muscle tenderness. However, inflammatory markers (e.g., ESR) and muscle enzymes (e.g., creatinine kinase) are typically elevated in inflammatory myopathies. This patient most likely has FM, in which muscle biopsy is not recommended.

Prednisone is used in the treatment of autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and polymyalgia rheumatica (PR). SLE affects women more often than men and can manifest with myalgias and fatigue. However, this patient does not have other common findings in SLE, such as skin involvement (e.g., the typical butterfly rash), joint pain, fever, and weight loss. PR mainly affects women older than 50 years of age and manifests with stiffness and pain in the shoulders, hips, or neck, as well as systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, malaise, and depressed mood). In contrast to what is seen in this patient, ESR is typically significantly elevated.

Although ketorolac is often used in the treatment of moderate to severe pain, treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and/or acetaminophen has not been proven effective in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

Regular exercise can reduce pain and improve functional capacity in patients with FM; cardiovascular training (e.g., swimming, walking, cycling) is recommended. Patients with FM should be advised to increase daily physical exercise gradually and that it is normal to initially experience a temporary worsening of myalgias. In addition, initial management of FM should include patient education (including reassurance about the disease and its prognosis and the importance of nonpharmacological measures such as sleep hygiene), treatment of comorbidities (e.g., mood and sleep disorders), and pharmacotherapy with low-dose tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline). Cyclobenzaprine, selective serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (e.g., duloxetine), or anticonvulsants (e.g., pregabalin, gabapentin) can also be used as initial pharmacotherapy.
Opioid therapy (e.g., with oxycodone) has not been proven effective in the treatment of chronic pain in patients with FM and should, therefore, be avoided.

question_text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of anxiety and mood changes. Four months ago, he was the driver and sole survivor in a motor vehicle collision that resulted in the deaths of his two brothers. He says, “I replay the moments before the crash in my mind every time I'm in a car.” He used to work as a delivery driver and had to take a leave of absence. He has not had nightmares or difficulty sleeping. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and a restricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy is initiated but does not lead to significant improvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of anxiety and mood changes. Four months ago, he was the driver and sole survivor in a motor vehicle collision that resulted in the deaths of his two brothers. He says, “I replay the moments before the crash in my mind every time I'm in a car.” He used to work as a delivery driver and had to take a leave of absence. He has not had nightmares or difficulty sleeping. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood and a restricted affect. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. Trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy is initiated but does not lead to significant improvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: This patient's history of trauma, repetitive intrusive memories, avoidance of driving, negative emotional state, and impaired occupational functioning for more than 1 month are features suggestive of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for posttraumatic stress disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Benzodiazepines (BDZs) like lorazepam can be used in patients experiencing anxiety. However, BZDs should generally be avoided in patients with PTSD because they have a high addiction potential and there is a lack of evidence supporting their benefits in the treatment of individuals with PTSD.

Prazosin can be used in patients with PTSD. However, prazosin is generally reserved for patients with PTSD with significant sleep disturbance or nightmares. Prazosin therapy is, therefore, not indicated in this patient at this point.

Second-generation antipsychotics like quetiapine can be used in patients with PTSD who fail to improve after two trials with different first-line medications and trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy. A different medication would be indicated as the first-line pharmacotherapy for this patient.

Selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) such as venlafaxine or selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as sertraline are indicated as first-line pharmacotherapy for patients with PTSD in whom trauma-focused psychotherapy was unsuccessful, as seen in this patient. SSRIs and SNRIs are effective in symptom reduction and treatment of concurrent psychiatric conditions (e.g., major depressive disorder) in patients with PTSD. Patients who respond poorly should be considered for management with a different SSRI or SNRI. If these treatment options are insufficient, second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., quetiapine, risperidone) can be considered to augment SSRIs and SNRIs or as monotherapy.

To remember the features of PTSD, think “TRAUMMA”: Traumatic event, Reexposure, Avoidance, Unable to function, More than a Month of duration, Arousal is increased.

Second-generation antipsychotics like risperidone can be used in patients with PTSD who fail to improve after two trials with different first-line medications and trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy. A different medication would be indicated as the first-line pharmacotherapy for this patient.

question_text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of behavior problems for the past 8 months. His parents report that he spends most of his free time in his room and often appears “distracted” when he comes out. During this time, he also has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain. He stopped attending soccer practice because he no longer enjoys it. He explains that he often lacks the motivation or is simply too tired to leave the house. He has trouble falling asleep at night and has failed several examinations in school. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has smoked cannabis regularly for the past year. He appears nervous. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, his speech is slow. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of behavior problems for the past 8 months. His parents report that he spends most of his free time in his room and often appears “distracted” when he comes out. During this time, he also has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain. He stopped attending soccer practice because he no longer enjoys it. He explains that he often lacks the motivation or is simply too tired to leave the house. He has trouble falling asleep at night and has failed several examinations in school. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He has smoked cannabis regularly for the past year. He appears nervous. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (194 lb); BMI is 28 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, his speech is slow. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition can cause insomnia and weight gain due to increased appetite.
learning_objective: Recognize cannabis use disorder.

answers.explanation_why: Persistent depressive disorder can manifest with fatigue, loss of energy, sleep disturbances (e.g., insomnia), slow speech, and weight gain. Affected individuals typically have a depressed mood for most of the day (in children and adolescents, the predominant mood symptom can be irritability). However, in children or adolescents, this condition can only be diagnosed after a 1-year period of symptoms (2 years for adults). This patient's symptoms have only occurred for the past 8 months. Moreover, the effects of a psychoactive substance must be excluded before establishing a diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder.

Normal adolescent behavior can include mood swings (e.g., lack of motivation), self-esteem issues, and an increase in risk-taking behavior (e.g., cannabis use). Adolescence is also associated with changes in body weight and composition. However, an inability to fulfill obligations at school, social withdrawal, and significant loss of interest in activities that used to be enjoyed are not considered normal adolescent behavior.

Personality disorders usually arise during late adolescence and cause impairment in social and/or occupational functioning. Individuals with schizoid personality disorder have voluntary detachment from social relationships, prefer solitary activities, and lack close friends. However, personality disorders do not cause a lack of motivation, fatigue, or sleep disturbances.

This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for cannabis use disorder. He regularly uses cannabis, is unable to fulfill obligations at school, exhibits social withdrawal, and has lost interest in activities he used to enjoy (e.g., attending soccer practice), all of which have occurred within the last year. Other manifestations of cannabis use disorder include a persistent desire or unsuccessful effort to decrease cannabis use, tolerance (e.g., more cannabis needed to achieve intoxication), and withdrawal (e.g., development of difficulty with sleep and/or mood changes after abrupt cessation of cannabis use). Treatment of cannabis use disorder includes psychosocial therapies, such as cognitive behavioral treatment and motivational interviewing.

Schizophrenia typically manifests in the late teens to mid-30s with a prodrome of negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, anhedonia, avolition). Symptoms must cause social, occupational, or personal functional impairment that lasts ≥ 6 months. Chronic cannabis use may increase the risk of developing schizophrenia. However, to meet the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia, ≥ 1 positive symptom of psychosis (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech) must be present.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sudden, intermittent “uncontrolled shivering” of her right arm and hand. Her symptoms began after she attended her grandmother's funeral 3 weeks ago. When she thinks about her grandmother, the shivering intensifies and spreads to her head and right leg. The intensity of the shivering declines when she works on her computer. She has major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows a high-amplitude tremor of the fully relaxed right arm with relative sparing of the fingers. The tremor increases in frequency during a finger-to-nose test. The patient is asked to tap with her left thumb and forefinger and follow a predetermined rhythm set by the physician's hand. When she does so, the frequency of the tremor in her right hand shifts to match the frequency of the tapping of her left hand. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient's tremor is best characterized as which of the following?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of sudden, intermittent “uncontrolled shivering” of her right arm and hand. Her symptoms began after she attended her grandmother's funeral 3 weeks ago. When she thinks about her grandmother, the shivering intensifies and spreads to her head and right leg. The intensity of the shivering declines when she works on her computer. She has major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. She appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows a high-amplitude tremor of the fully relaxed right arm with relative sparing of the fingers. The tremor increases in frequency during a finger-to-nose test. The patient is asked to tap with her left thumb and forefinger and follow a predetermined rhythm set by the physician's hand. When she does so, the frequency of the tremor in her right hand shifts to match the frequency of the tapping of her left hand. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. This patient's tremor is best characterized as which of the following?
hint: A positive entrainment test is used to diagnose this type of tremor.
learning_objective: Recognize functional tremor.

answers.explanation_why: Essential tremor is a postural tremor that typically affects the hands and head, worsens with voluntary movement and/or an anxious state, and is associated with an otherwise normal neurological examination. An essential tremor may be accompanied by an intention tremor and/or a resting tremor. However, essential tremor is most commonly symmetric and slowly progressive, whereas this patient presents with an asymmetric tremor that started promptly. Finally, this patient's tremor is of variable frequency, intensity, and affects various body parts, which is suggestive of another type of tremor.

Resting tremor occurs when the affected body part is fully relaxed and supported against gravity (e.g., hands resting on a table). This type of tremor is typically asymmetric, starts unilateral, affects the extremities, and worsens with emotional stress. Unlike this patient's tremor, which diminishes with distraction, resting tremor subsides with voluntary movements. Resting tremor is typically associated with Parkinson disease.

Intention tremor is most commonly caused by cerebellar lesions (e.g., stroke, trauma, multiple sclerosis). Patients present with a coarse hand tremor that is aggravated by goal-directed movements (i.e., increases in frequency during a finger-to-nose test). However, this patient lacks other features of cerebellar dysfunction (e.g., ataxia, gait instability, dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria).

Functional tremor typically has an abrupt onset and is triggered by a physical (e.g., injury), somatic (e.g., migraine headache), or psychological event (e.g., death of a family member). This condition is characterized by quick progression to severe symptoms, significant functional disability, and changing of amplitude, frequency, and/or distribution of movement over time. Affected individuals may present with a complex combination of resting, postural, or action tremors that occur simultaneously. Functional tremor typically worsens under direct observation and diminishes with distraction (e.g., while working on the computer). The condition is often associated with psychiatric disorders (e.g., functional neurological symptom disorder, anxiety disorder, depression). Patients are usually unresponsive to drugs for organic movement disorders, but may be responsive to placebo or psychotherapy (e.g., cognitive-behavioral therapy).

Physiologic tremor is a postural tremor that is enhanced with sympathetic stimulation (e.g., anxiety, stress) and usually affects the hands. While physiological tremor can be a manifestation of an underlying condition (e.g., hypoglycemia, hyperthyroidism, drug withdrawal), it is not caused by an underlying neurologic disease. This type of tremor is typically fine and symmetric, whereas this patient presents with an asymmetric, high-amplitude tremor.

question_text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. Until now, he has never talked to a physician about his concerns because he feels embarrassed. He recently read in an article that approximately 1 in every 20 men experiences similar problems, which gave him the courage to come to the office today. He says that he cannot fully enjoy his sexual life and tries to avoid sexual intimacy although he feels attracted to his partner. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of concerns about his sexual performance for the past 3 years. The patient says that every time he sleeps with his life partner, within 30 seconds after penetration he has an orgasm which he cannot delay by any of the methods he has found on the internet. He has not had problems achieving an erection and cannot recall a triggering event for his concerns. Until now, he has never talked to a physician about his concerns because he feels embarrassed. He recently read in an article that approximately 1 in every 20 men experiences similar problems, which gave him the courage to come to the office today. He says that he cannot fully enjoy his sexual life and tries to avoid sexual intimacy although he feels attracted to his partner. He is happy with all other aspects of his relationship and personal life. He has hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia. Medications are chlorthalidone, losartan, and tamsulosin. He does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Genitourinary examination shows no scrotal or penile abnormalities. In addition to recommending behavioral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for premature ejaculation in the absence of erectile dysfunction. The next step in management takes advantage of the side effect profile of a specific drug.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for premature ejaculation.

answers.explanation_why: Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (PDE5 inhibitors) such as sildenafil can be used in patients with premature ejaculation who have concomitant erectile dysfunction. This patient has isolated premature ejaculation, for which sildenafil therapy is not indicated. Moreover, PDE5 inhibitors should be used with caution in patients who take alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

Tamsulosin is a sympatholytic drug used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Because of its sympatholytic properties, this drug can cause delayed ejaculation, as this process is stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system. Discontinuation is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient with premature ejaculation.

Propranolol is a nonselective beta blocker that acts as a sympatholytic drug. Although ejaculation is primarily stimulated by the sympathetic nervous system, beta blockers do not play a role in the treatment of premature ejaculation. Beta blockers may cause erectile dysfunction, a different sexual disorder, and discontinuation of these drugs should be considered in patients with erectile dysfunction.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), such as paroxetine, are used first-line but off-label for the treatment of premature ejaculation in patients without concomitant erectile dysfunction. The indication takes advantage of the side effect profile of SSRIs, which includes ejaculatory delay (up to 9 minutes for paroxetine) and orgasm disturbance. In addition to SSRIs, topical anesthetics (e.g., lidocaine-prilocaine spray) can be used to reduce the sensitivity of the penis and thereby decrease sexual stimulation. In addition to medical therapy, behavioral therapy can be offered to patients with significant psychological distress (e.g., lack of self-confidence, impaired life quality) and to those in whom psychogenic factors (e.g., anxiety, depression) play a role in the development of premature ejaculation.

In patients with concomitant erectile dysfunction, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) are used first-line because premature ejaculation is often an outcome of erectile dysfunction. Note that this drug class should be used with caution in patients who are treated with alpha-receptor blockers, such as tamsulosin, because of a risk of orthostatic hypotension.

Chlorthalidone is a thiazide diuretic that can cause erectile dysfunction. This patient has premature ejaculation without erectile dysfunction. Discontinuation of chlorthalidone is unlikely to provide any benefit to this patient.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. The mother reports that she and her husband have been monitoring their son's voiding habits over the past month. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. He drinks little during dinner and before going to bed. They have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-month history of bedwetting about 2–3 times per week. He previously went 1 year without wetting the bed. The mother reports that she and her husband have been monitoring their son's voiding habits over the past month. He passes stool of normal color and consistency approximately once daily and voids his bladder 5–7 times per day. He drinks little during dinner and before going to bed. They have not noticed any urgency, hesitancy, straining, postmicturition dribble, or episodes of urinary incontinence during the day. The patient says that he has no pain in his abdominal or genital region prior to, during, or after voiding. He recently started primary school and says he enjoys it. He is able to balance and hop on one foot, tie a knot, name 6 colors, and dress with minimal assistance from his parents. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A child who previously achieved nocturnal continence and has begun to wet the bed again has secondary enuresis.
learning_objective: Recognize secondary enuresis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Desmopressin therapy is indicated for patients ≥ 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis if nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, timed voiding, enuresis alarm) are unsuccessful or if more rapid improvement is desired. However, organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

Urological imaging (e.g., a voiding cystourethrogram) is used to diagnose urinary tract abnormalities in patients with secondary enuresis who have findings such as symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, a history of multiple urinary tract infections, and significant urinary symptoms during the daytime. This patient has no such findings that suggest urinary tract abnormalities.

Urinalysis is indicated in all patients with nocturnal enuresis to exclude organic causes, such as occult urinary tract infection, diabetic ketoacidosis, and diabetes insipidus. In addition to urinalysis, a detailed history, a voiding diary, and a physical examination should be completed prior to initiating treatment. Secondary enuresis is typically caused by an underlying condition (e.g., constipation, obstructive sleep apnea, urinary tract abnormalities, certain psychiatric disorders) or new psychosocial stressors (e.g., starting primary school). Treatment includes nonpharmacological measures (e.g., fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation, timed voiding), training with an enuresis alarm, pharmacotherapy (e.g., desmopressin), and management of any underlying conditions (e.g., antibiotics for urinary tract infection).

Enuresis alarms are a first-line therapy for patients < 7 years of age with nocturnal enuresis who do not respond to behavioral modifications (e.g., timed voiding, fluid restriction at night, psychoeducation). However, this patient is 7 years old, and organic causes of secondary enuresis should be ruled out before initiating treatment.

Reassurance and follow-up are appropriate for children < 5 years because bedwetting is normal for this age. This patient is 7 years old and presents with secondary enuresis, which warrants another step in management.

question_text:
Patient information
Age: 64 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: hospital
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: evaluation 12 hours after admission for alcohol intoxication
History of Present Illness:

brought to the emergency department by law enforcement authorities after being arrested for driving under the influence of alcohol
blood alcohol concentration at the time of admission was 250 mg/dL

patient is currently not inebriated but reports alcohol cravings
patient does not recall events leading up to the arrest and is not concerned

Past Medical History: 

hyperlipidemia
hospitalized once 3 years ago for alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Medications:
atorvastatin
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
father: history of alcohol use disorder; committed suicide at age 54 years

Psychosocial History: 

does not smoke or use illicit drugs

drinks 4–5 12-oz beers and ½ bottle of wine daily; started drinking as a teenager; unsuccessfully attempted an outpatient rehab program for alcohol use at the age of 45 years

currently undergoing divorce; separated from wife for 2 years because of aggressive behavior
lost his job as a tax consultant 2 months ago because of alcohol use at work

Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S_1 and S_2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: soft; mild tenderness to palpation over the right upper quadrant; hepatomegaly

Which of the following is the strongest indicator of the severity of this patient's alcohol use disorder?

hint: This patient meets the diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder (AUD). The more criteria the patient meets, the more severe the condition.
learning_objective: Recognize the diagnostic criteria for alcohol use disorder and their role in assessing its severity.

answers.content: Age at onset of alcohol use
answers.explanation_why: Alcohol use at a young age increases the risk of developing AUD but is not a diagnostic criterion for AUD nor an indicator of its severity.

Alcohol use disorder (AUD) is a clinical diagnosis that is confirmed if two out of 11 DSM-5 criteria for AUD are met within the past 12 months. These criteria are based on the patient's medical and psychosocial history and include continued drinking despite knowing that physical or psychological problems are likely to have resulted from alcohol use, continued drinking despite exacerbation of social or interpersonal problems (e.g., divorce), inability to fulfill work obligations, clinical features of alcohol withdrawal syndrome, persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to reduce drinking, and drinking in physically hazardous situations (e.g., driving). AUD severity is classified as mild, moderate, or severe based on the number of criteria met. This patient meets several diagnostic criteria for AUD. Assessing the severity of AUD is important for the choice of treatment. Psychosocial intervention alone is the preferred treatment for mild AUD, while a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychosocial intervention is recommended for patients with moderate or severe AUD.

answers.content: Family history of alcohol use disorder
answers.explanation_why: Although a positive family history increases the risk of developing AUD, it is neither a diagnostic criterion nor an indicator of its severity.

Blood alcohol levels can confirm recent alcohol use within 12 hours of the last drink but do not indicate regular heavy drinking. Instead, tests like carbohydrate-deficient transferrin levels, phosphatidylethanol levels, and markers of end-organ damage (e.g., abnormal liver chemistries) assess alcohol use severity.

question_text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 20-minute history of lightheadedness, chest pain, and feeling like she is not getting enough air. The symptoms started suddenly after she had an argument with her best friend. She has experienced similar symptoms that resolved spontaneously within a few minutes. She says that she cannot predict when the episodes occur but has no symptoms persisting after. She works in an office and enjoys socializing with her colleagues after work. She has no history of traumatic events or serious illness and takes no medications. She drinks a few beers on the weekends and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows frequent sighing and exaggerated deep breaths. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Leukocyte count
6000/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+ 

141 mEq/L

 K^+

4.1 mEq/L

 Cl^-

99 mEq/L

 Glucose
77 mg/dL

 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL

 Thyroid-stimulating hormone
2.4 μU/mL

 Troponin I
0.02 ng/mL

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.49

Pco_2
25 mm Hg

Po_2

113 mm Hg

HCO_3-

20 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 20-minute history of lightheadedness, chest pain, and feeling like she is not getting enough air. The symptoms started suddenly after she had an argument with her best friend. She has experienced similar symptoms that resolved spontaneously within a few minutes. She says that she cannot predict when the episodes occur but has no symptoms persisting after. She works in an office and enjoys socializing with her colleagues after work. She has no history of traumatic events or serious illness and takes no medications. She drinks a few beers on the weekends and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows frequent sighing and exaggerated deep breaths. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 6000/mm3 Serum Na+ 141 mEq/L K+ 4.1 mEq/L Cl- 99 mEq/L Glucose 77 mg/dL Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL Thyroid-stimulating hormone 2.4 μU/mL Troponin I 0.02 ng/mL Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.49 Pco2 25 mm Hg Po2 113 mm Hg HCO3- 20 mEq/L Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with lightheadedness, chest pain, transient hyperventilation (tachypnea, exaggerated deep breaths) and mild respiratory alkalosis on arterial blood gas analysis, but other diagnostic studies show no abnormalities, which is consistent with acute hyperventilation syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize acute hyperventilation syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Breathing retraining (focused on diaphragmatic breathing), removal of stressors, and reassurance are the most appropriate steps for patients with hyperventilation syndrome. Because the condition is a diagnosis of exclusion, it is necessary to evaluate for organic causes (e.g., myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, diabetic ketoacidosis, asthma) that can manifest with episodic hyperventilation, lightheadedness, and chest pain. Hyperventilation syndrome is frequently associated with anxiety and/or panic disorders. This patient shows mild respiratory alkalosis on arterial blood gas analysis, but laboratory studies, ECG, and chest x-ray show no abnormalities, which is consistent with hyperventilation syndrome.

Although paper bag rebreathing was once preferred to increase the fraction of inspired CO_2 in the setting of acute hyperventilation, this technique can cause significant hypoxemia and is therefore no longer recommended.

SNRIs such as venlafaxine, or SSRIs, are the first-line pharmacological treatment for social anxiety disorder (SAD), which can manifest with lightheadedness, chest pain, and hyperventilation. However, in SAD, symptoms are connected to social situations (e.g., parties, public speaking) and are associated with the intense and disproportionate fear of being judged or scrutinized, none of which is seen in this patient. Individuals with SAD experience anticipatory anxiety (e.g., worrying weeks in advance about attending an event) and usually try to avoid triggering situations (e.g., refusing to attend school). SNRIs and SSRIs do not provide immediate symptom relief, and they typically require days or weeks of continued use to take effect.

Short-acting oral benzodiazepines, such as alprazolam, are an appropriate second-line treatment option for hyperventilation syndrome and for acute panic attacks if nonpharmacological options fail. Acute panic attack is diagnosed in individuals with ≥ 4 cognitive and/or somatic symptoms, but this patient only has 3 (lightheadedness, chest pain, and shortness of breath). Panic attacks occur unpredictably and usually last for several minutes before resolving on their own. Individuals with panic disorder are typically persistently worried about future panic attacks and their consequences and may engage in maladaptive behavior to avoid further episodes.

In patients with chest pain, the pretest probability of CAD based on the patient's age, gender, and type of chest pain (nonanginal, atypical anginal, or typical anginal) is used to determine the necessity of further cardiac stress testing. Because this patient's chest pain occurs exclusively during episodes of acute hyperventilation and is not related to physical exertion, her pretest probability of CAD is low and does not require further cardiac testing.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not been feeling like herself after her brother died in a car accident 4 months ago. She says, “The day my brother died, my soul left my body.” Since the accident, she has had daily stomachaches and has lost interest in food, resulting in a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. During this time, she has also been tired constantly because she has trouble falling asleep and frequently wakes up from nightmares. She recently immigrated from Mexico. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m^2. Examination, including abdominal examination, shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented but has a sad mood and flat affect. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has not been feeling like herself after her brother died in a car accident 4 months ago. She says, “The day my brother died, my soul left my body.” Since the accident, she has had daily stomachaches and has lost interest in food, resulting in a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss. During this time, she has also been tired constantly because she has trouble falling asleep and frequently wakes up from nightmares. She recently immigrated from Mexico. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Examination, including abdominal examination, shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is alert and oriented but has a sad mood and flat affect. Results of laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
hint: Susto is an illness in certain cultures (e.g., Latin America) in which the soul is understood to leave the body. This condition typically occurs after stressful life events and can manifest with somatic and psychological symptoms.
learning_objective: Recognize cultural influences on health beliefs, and choose an appropriate initial response to explore the patient's understanding of their illness.

answers.content: "This must be very hard for you. The death of a loved one is a common cause of depression."
answers.explanation_why: This statement is inappropriate because it directly confronts the patient with a diagnosis that is likely different from her understanding of her condition, and there may be stigma around psychiatric disorders (e.g., depression) in some cultures. As a result, patients often present with atypical somatic symptoms (e.g., back pain, stomachache) and may be reluctant to accept a psychiatric diagnosis. Therefore, the patient's cultural background should be considered when addressing a diagnosis.

answers.content: "We should discuss one symptom at a time. Why don't we begin with your sleeping problems?”
answers.explanation_why: Physicians should consider medical necessity when prioritizing concerns. However, this patient is not primarily suffering from a sleep disorder, but rather coping with a stressful life event. Simply focusing on one symptom is inappropriate in this scenario and may be perceived to be dismissive of the patient's beliefs.

answers.content: "What is your understanding of what is happening to you?"
answers.explanation_why:
This is the most appropriate initial response because it helps the physician explore the patient's beliefs about their illness before making a diagnosis or treatment decision. Open-ended questions allow the physician to gain insights into the patient's understanding of their illness, thereby allowing an empathetic response and encouraging further discussion. Patients may describe their symptoms or states of distress differently depending on their cultural background (e.g., religion, national origin, ethnicity, education), and there may be stigma around psychiatric disorders (e.g., depression) in some cultures. As a result, patients often present with atypical somatic symptoms (e.g., back pain, stomachache) and may be reluctant to accept a psychiatric diagnosis. Therefore, acknowledging the individual's beliefs with a culturally competent, patient-centered approach is necessary to avoid misdiagnosis and allow empathetic communication and management.

Cultural syndromes (e.g., susto, dhat syndrome) are clusters of psychological and/or somatic symptoms that can occur in certain cultures or contexts and may be recognized as legitimate medical conditions in their respective communities.

answers.content: "Over the past 4 months, have you been bothered by little interest or pleasure in doing things?"
answers.explanation_why: Although asking for further symptoms of depression is important, the physician should consider the patient's cultural background and explore her individual needs before asking close-ended screening questions.

answers.content: "I can assure you that your symptoms are not caused by your soul leaving your body."
answers.explanation_why: This statement is inappropriate because it dismisses the patient's beliefs and emotions. The physician should consider the patient's cultural background and individual needs and show compassion and empathy in order to diagnose and manage them successfully.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder comes to the psychiatrist for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, she started treatment with fluoxetine because of persistent feelings of emptiness and self-injurious behavior. She has been receiving dialectical behavior therapy from a clinical psychologist for the past year. Before the initiation of pharmacotherapy, the psychiatrist and psychologist met face-to-face to exchange clinical information and establish mutual treatment goals. The patient agreed to the treatment plan, which included both pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy. The patient reports that she stopped going to psychotherapy for 2 weeks because the psychologist is a "traitor" who manipulates her emotions. The patient says that she only trusts the psychiatrist, who she describes as “my personal hero,” and wants to continue pharmacotherapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman with borderline personality disorder comes to the psychiatrist for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, she started treatment with fluoxetine because of persistent feelings of emptiness and self-injurious behavior. She has been receiving dialectical behavior therapy from a clinical psychologist for the past year. Before the initiation of pharmacotherapy, the psychiatrist and psychologist met face-to-face to exchange clinical information and establish mutual treatment goals. The patient agreed to the treatment plan, which included both pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy. The patient reports that she stopped going to psychotherapy for 2 weeks because the psychologist is a "traitor" who manipulates her emotions. The patient says that she only trusts the psychiatrist, who she describes as “my personal hero,” and wants to continue pharmacotherapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
hint: The patient idealizes her psychiatrist and distrusts her psychologist. This defense mechanism, referred to as splitting, is characteristic of borderline personality disorder (BPD).
learning_objective: Recognize and address splitting behavior in patients with borderline personality disorder.

answers.content: "I will discuss this with your psychologist and let you know our decision."
answers.explanation_why: Providers may share relevant patient information (except for psychotherapy notes and substance use disorder treatment records) without a waiver of confidentiality. However, making a treatment plan without involving the patient in the decision-making process is inappropriate.

answers.content: "Quitting psychotherapy is only possible if we increase your visits to this practice.”
answers.explanation_why: This statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting and does not involve all members of the multiple-provider team in decision-making. Additionally, pharmacotherapy plays a complementary role, while psychotherapy (e.g., dialectical behavioral therapy) is the first-line treatment for patients with BPD.

answers.content: “It would make sense for you to choose a different psychologist."
answers.explanation_why: Because splitting (psychiatry) endangers adherence, changes in the treatment plan may be necessary. However, this statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting, and changing providers may be counterproductive at this time.

answers.content: "When setting your treatment goals, you agreed to attend sessions with your psychologist."
answers.explanation_why:
Treatment for BPD can be challenging because patients may project their feelings onto their providers (e.g., fear of abandonment) or respond to therapy with psychological defense mechanisms. Although a patient always has the right to choose a different provider or to opt out of treatment entirely, they should be encouraged to adhere to the existing treatment plan. In a multiple-provider setting, providers can support each other when patients are resistant to treatment.

In this scenario, the psychiatrist should remind the patient of the treatment goals and encourage adherence to therapy. All providers involved in patient care should collaborate toward common treatment goals (e.g., emotional stability, improved relationships). Regular communication, clarification of roles, and plans for crisis management (e.g., whom to call in case of an emergency) are necessary in a multiple-provider setting.

answers.content: "If this is your decision, we can pause psychotherapy for 3 months"
answers.explanation_why: This statement is inappropriate because it encourages splitting. Providers should collaborate with each other and work as a team towards mutual treatment goals. In addition, all members of a multiple-provider team should be involved in making decisions.
